headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Alliance Data First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In order to view the company's presentation on their website, please remember to turn off the pop-up blocker on your computer. It is now
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Alliance Data First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In order to view the company's presentation on their website, please remember to turn off the pop-up blocker on your computer. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Steve Calk of FTI Consulting. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. By now you should have received a copy of the company's first quarter 2016 earnings release. If you have not, please call FTI Consulting at (212) 850-5721. On the call today, we have Ed Heffernan, President and Chief Executive Offic
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. By now you should have received a copy of the company's first quarter 2016 earnings release. If you have not, please call FTI Consulting at (212) 850-5721. 
On the call today, we have Ed Heffernan, President and Chief Executive Officer of Alliance Data; Charles Horn, Chief Financial Officer of Alliance Data; and Bryan Pearson, President and Chief Executive Officer of LoyaltyOne. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that some of the comments made on today's call and some of the responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to the risks and uncertainties described in the company's earnings release and other filings with the SEC. Alliance Data has no obligation to update the information presented on the call. 
Also on today's call, our speakers will reference certain non-GAAP financial measures, which we believe will provide useful information for investors. Reconciliation of those measures to GAAP will be posted on the Investor Relations website at www.alliancedata.com.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Ed Heffernan. Ed?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. With me today, as mentioned, is Charles Horn, our CFO; and Bryan Pearson, Head of our LoyaltyOne business, and that includes both the AIR MILES business in Canada as well as the BrandLoyalty business headquartered out of the Netherlands. Ch
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. With me today, as mentioned, is Charles Horn, our CFO; and Bryan Pearson, Head of our LoyaltyOne business, and that includes both the AIR MILES business in Canada as well as the BrandLoyalty business headquartered out of the Netherlands. Charles will update you on the quarterly results. Bryan will give you some color into the various businesses at LoyaltyOne, and I'll wrap it up with the score card Q1 results, as well as my outlook for full year 2016. Based on past comments, we're going to move with pace so we can have more time for questions at the end. Take it away, Charles.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Turning to Slide 2, we'll talk about the first quarter results, and they were pretty much as we expected, with the revenue up [ph] 5% to $1.68 billion and quarter [indiscernible] EPS of $3.84. It was a quarter with several positives but also a
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed. Turning to Slide 2, we'll talk about the first quarter results, and they were pretty much as we expected, with the revenue up [ph] 5% to $1.68 billion and quarter [indiscernible] EPS of $3.84. It was a quarter with several positives but also a few negatives that tempered overall results. One of the negatives, foreign exchange rates, reduced both revenue end quarter EPS by about 2 points for the first quarter. The good news is that FX rates seem to have stabilized and the drag could drop to near zero in the back half of 2016.
Looking forward, we expect growth in each quarter to accelerate as 2016 progresses. Revenue growth of 5% in Q1 is expected to increase to 8% in Q2 and then double-digit growth in Q3 and Q4. Adjusted EBITDA and core EPS are expected to follow a similar trend. 
Now why do we believe this? Putting aside improving foreign-exchange comparables, there are several reasons. First, gross yield compression at Card Services should lessen each quarter as we anniversary several program changes made last year. Second, loss rates were expected to drift downward from first quarter highs. Third, BrandLoyalty has passed its most difficult comparable. If you remember in first quarter 2015, the revenue was up over 100% on a constant currency basis. 
Lastly, Epsilon's agency weakness should lessen, coupled with a record year end backlog per second half delivery. During the quarter, we acquired 2 million shares under our repurchase program for approximately $440 million. The buyback program remains our top capital allocation priority and we expect will be executed somewhat ratably over the remainder of 2016. Essentially, we will look to deploy our free cash flow while maintaining the leverage ratio of less than 3x.
[indiscernible] on the next slide and Bryan will walk you through the Q1 results.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charles. LoyaltyOne had a better-than-expected quarter as revenue decreased 2% to $381 million, but adjusted EBITDA increased 10% to $85 million on a constant currency basis. Breaking it down further, at AIR MILES our revenue increased 4% and adju
componenttext:
Thanks, Charles. LoyaltyOne had a better-than-expected quarter as revenue decreased 2% to $381 million, but adjusted EBITDA increased 10% to $85 million on a constant currency basis. Breaking it down further, at AIR MILES our revenue increased 4% and adjusted EBITDA increased a robust 11% on a constant currency basis, and that was driven by a favorable issuance mix and prudent cost controls. 
As expected at BrandLoyalty, revenue was down 9% on a constant currency basis due to program timing differences. Encouragingly, adjusted EBITDA increased 9% on a constant currency basis due to higher margin programs that were driving a 300 basis points expansion in adjusted EBITDA margins.
AIR MILES issued increased a robust 5% or 57 million miles over the same quarter from last year. Issuance was particularly strong with our financial vertical as we continue to convert BMO MasterCard holders to the Premium World Elite card that had a more compelling consumer proposition and a higher AIR MILES earn offer. This strong growth was achieved despite economic uncertainty in Western Canada that's a result of the declining global oil prices that has been negatively impacting activity at our grocery partners, and also the suspension of point issuance on prescriptions in British Columbia.
Looking ahead, we anticipate a 2% decline in issuance growth through the second quarter due to reduced promotional activity and the one-time conversion of the Sobeys legacy program that happened in 2015, which of course would not be repeated.
As we have stated previously, quarterly results can vary based on the timing of promotional activity, but our target remains a full year issuance growth of mid-single digits. 
AIR MILES redeemed increased 6% compared to the first quarter of 2015 with our AIR MILES cash program, that instant reward option, driving approximately half of the increase as its liquidity feature resonates with collectors in the current macro environment.
For the full year, we anticipate redemption growth to be in line with issuance growth. 
For the year, we anticipate full year constant currency revenue and adjusted EBITDA growth for AIR MILES to be in the mid-single digit range as well.
Now turning to BrandLoyalty. We anticipate a very strong second quarter whereby revenue could be up as much as 50% on a constant currency basis. On the North American expansion front, BrandLoyalty continues to increase its presence in Canada with sticks promotions that have been planned for 2016, and this represents a significant increase in sales over last year.
In addition, we launched our first pilot in the U.S. late in the first quarter. We were pleased with the results to date and look forward to additional programs in this market. The full year expectation for BrandLoyalty continues to be midteens growth in both revenue and adjusted EBITDA as compared to 2015 on a constant currency basis.
Lastly, let me update you on Dotz and Precima. Starting with Dotz, our Brazilian coalition program, where we continue to see steady growth in our collector based to over 18 million currently. In November of last year, Dotz successfully launched the coalition program in Rio de Janeiro with the [indiscernible] grocery banner called [indiscernible] as a key partner.
[indiscernible] is the third-largest grocery in Brazil and collector reception has been positive, with over 1 million collectors now enrolled and active in Rio. 
Precima, our data analytics unit, continues to fire on all cylinders, recently signing a deal with Morrison, one of the UK's top 4 grocers, where we will apply data intelligence and shopper insights to help Morrisons effectively apply their customer-centric retailing approach.
In closing, LoyaltyOne achieve solid Q1 results with a positive outlook for the remainder of 2016. I'd like to take this opportunity to congratulate the entire team on a great quarter and look forward to their commitment to our valued clients and to LoyaltyOne. Awesome job, everyone. Back to you, Charles.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Let's turn to Slide 4. Epsilon's revenue decreased 2% to $493 million and [indiscernible] decreased 22% to $81 million for the first quarter of 2016. Results in this segment were mixed at 3/4 of the business, digital and technology platform
componenttext:
Thanks, Bryan. Let's turn to Slide 4. Epsilon's revenue decreased 2% to $493 million and [indiscernible] decreased 22% to $81 million for the first quarter of 2016. Results in this segment were mixed at 3/4 of the business, digital and technology platforms grew at best 8% during the quarter, while the remaining 1/4, agency reforms where revenues declined by 23% versus the first quarter 2015. Adjusted EBITDA decreased $23 million from the first quarter of 2015, primarily due to higher payroll costs, staffing levels increase in anticipation of revenue that is yet to occur.
Before we dive into the individual portions, you see that we have a new reporting format here. We thought that the old formats which we talked about database and data support is really not reflective with the way we go with business these days. Specifically, is the broad portfolio of off-line, online services Epsilon delivers our package for bundle, omnichannel solutions, it just doesn't make sense for us to get into the format. So what we've done is we put this together and we're going to highlight 2 categories that represent the underlying services and assets deployed to serve our clients. 
The first category, digital and technology platforms, consists of businesses which primarily drives from revenues tied to one of the many core data or technology platforms that Epsilon can manage. These platforms are used to house and manage data in real-time, to analyze and model data, and to automate the usage of that data across a variety of channels, whether it be through our loyalty program within e-mail communication or an online message delivery on mobile or desktop devices.
The remainder of the business, agency media and services, consist of services which are primarily focus on supporting the agency sector. Both media services delivered agencies on behalf of their clients as well as agency engagements in which Epsilon acts as a primary agency directly on behalf of its clients.
Now let's turn to the digital and technology portion of this segment, where quarterly revenue grew by $28 [ph] million year-over-year or about 8% mostly due to continued success of the cross-sell efforts and on boarding of strong CRM backlog within Conversant. The products offered within the CRM business continued to resonate with both new and existing clients, as 50 new contract have already been signed this year versus 30, all of last year. The 2016 vintage thus far includes GMC, Brooks Brothers, Coach and Sears as a great follow-up to last year's efforts. These clients along with others such as Walgreens, are connecting with real people as a result of combining an automized first party with third-party data and $80 billion daily online interactions to develop a persistent consumer ID.
Moving on to agency media and services, revenue declined 23% from the first quarter of 2015. Perhaps launched Epsilon's traditional business, we see broad-based weakness, especially in the telco, CPG and retail verticals. In addition, the agency business to conversant which is the nondata driven traditional display business was down as large agencies push more programmatic buying due to internal platforms versus using third-party DSPs.
We don't know if this bubble is a bubble with an agency or more structural needs to play out as the year progresses. If it's structural, we have to be more aggressive going after cost cuts to maintain our earnings. Although it will likely continue to volatility within agency on a quarterly basis, it is our key part of the CMO selling process which attracts more broad and less IT-centric relationships.
Now let's go over to the next slide and talk about Card Services. Card Services delivered strong financial results, achieving a 17 consecutive quarter of double-digit revenue growth. Revenue increased 17% for the first quarter of 2016, driven by 27% increase in average receivables. Adjusted EBITDA net grew 9%, dampened slightly by the provision builds. Importantly, principal loss rates were 5.2% for the quarter, 10 basis points better than our original guidance.
Focusing on the key drivers for our growth. Credit sales increased a healthy 25%, driven by our proven ability to grow customer loyalty for both our long-standing and through its brand partners, as well as favorable weather and an early Easter. Our core business, brand partners with us for 4 years or more, continue to contribute roughly half of our credit sales growth. Importantly, we continue to grow tender share, up over 200 basis points for the first quarter by leveraging our large understanding of our brands along with the deep data analytics we bring to bear.
Most of the tender share pickup is being driven the card members have been engage with their card for multiple years, not from new accounts. In other words, these are tenured cardmembers with a proven spending and payment history and they are demonstrating increased spend with the brands they love. This is a testament to the power of our customized marketing programs and the value they deliver to our long-standing partners. It's also a key differentiator and critical element in our ability to welcome new partners.
Looking at the remaining drivers of our performance, we talked about revenue grew 17% driven by the strong air [ph] growth. importantly, we really strong operating expense leverage as we are able to chop our expense ratio by 70 bps during the quarter. 
As expected, gross yields experience some compression driven primarily by brand mix, accounting for acquired files and lower late fees as we obtain several declined for several months in our first stage delinquency bucket. This pressure is predominantly in the first half of the year, and we expect the yields to normalize as we anniversary these guidance.
Managing losses was key in the first quarter, and we exceeded guidance previously outlined. Losses delinquency levels and  [indiscernible] in line were both expectations and seasonal trends. During the quarter, we decided not to renew card programs for renewal at [indiscernible]. The related receivables net of the allowance for loan loss has been reclassified to assets held for sale at March 31, 2016. Accordingly, $430 million has been removed from card receivables and $15 [ph] million has been removed from the allowance for loan loss. 
Our reserve for loan losses was 5.7% of reservable receivables at March 31, 2016, up from 5.5% at December 31, 2015. Reserve dollars dropped by $15 million from December 31, due to the reclassification previously discussed. 
In closing for Card Services, we delivered another stellar quarter with all the key metrics outpacing the industry and consistent with our expectations. We are positioned for another record year in line with our strategy of 20% plus credit sales and AR growth, leveraging both organic growth and new partnerships.
With that, I'll turn it over to Ed.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, guys. When we turn to first quarter scorecard and the goal, of course, is to have more greens than yellows and reds, and right now, we're tracking with 30 being green. I would say in terms of Q1 a couple of general comments, one is, as Char
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, guys. When we turn to first quarter scorecard and the goal, of course, is to have more greens than yellows and reds, and right now, we're tracking with 30 being green. I would say in terms of Q1 a couple of general comments, one is, as Charles mentioned, this was obviously our toughest quarter. Comp versus last year was very difficult. And putting in a plus 5 top, plus 5 earnings, was right on the money of what we wanted to do. And our view into the rest of the year looks solid. So it's good to get that behind us.
Also, you'll find that it was kind of a mixed bag in terms of what it got us from A to B. But at the end, the pluses sort of outweighed the minuses and we got where we wanted to be.
As we move into the second quarter and the rest of the year, things are accelerating nicely. We have a good line of sight into the rest of the year. From our first quarter perspective, consolidated, we came right in where we said in terms of guidance at about $1.7 billion top and about $384 million [ph] on earnings. That was -- that included getting hit on the FX side with about $26 million in top and about $0.05 [ph] on earnings from FX, which, if it holds, will fortunately start to anniversary as we move into the back half. 
We talked about the toughest comp of the years now behind us, and we were pretty active in the buyback, taking in a bunch of shares which we thought were pretty cheap.
So overall consolidated, we got where we wanted to be and remain on track for the year in Card Services. Just the highlights, of course, the portfolio continues to grow very quickly, with over 20% growth, revenue in the high teens. And then obviously, due to the fact that we're growing so quickly, we need to obviously set up reserves and that tends to be a damper on EBITDA. Nonetheless, they grow 9%. 
Yields get the yellow, it was a little over 200 basis points due to multiple factors that we can talk about. Again, the good news there is that it's already beginning to burn away, and we expect less compression as each quarter goes by for the year, and we have pretty good visibility into that as well. So more of a Q1 issue. 
The loss rate, we spent the first 3 months of the year here dealing with 2 questions that people were spooked about, the first being credit quality, and the second being Canada going into a depression. And what's interesting is those are the 2 items that probably performed best during the quarter. Credit quality actually came in a little bit better than we had anticipated. We now expect it to drift downwards as the year progresses from a seasonally high Q1. And similar to what we said 3 months ago, we'll say the same thing now. We check with our collectors and everyone else. There is 0 pressure that we're seeing coming in, that would suggest that there's any type of stress on the consumer at this point. So we're just not seeing it. We didn't see it before. And again, we're just normalizing the loss rates in the file, which right now we're tracking nicely to that.
I will emphasize the next point which is tender share. That's often lost in all these discussions about growth and are you growing too fast, too strongly, how are you growing? Is it good quality, bad quality and all that other stuff. Tender share is up 200 basis points, which means if 30% of the sales at a retailer were on our card a year ago, now it's 32%. And that is not being moved by putting on a bunch of new accounts. And in fact, what it essentially means is that when the retailers growing 2%, 3%, we're growing 10%. And so the first 10 points of portfolio growth are coming from a deeper penetration of that retailer sales base. And the next bullet point to me really brings it home that 80% of this tender share again, they're coming from the mature accounts. They're coming from accounts that have been with us for 20, 24 months or more, which means they passed the peak sort of loss point. And they're very mature. And our ability to get in there and motivate incremental spend is really what it's all about. That's the data-driven targeted marketing. And I think that's probably the most important take away is that this is not coming from a bunch of whole new accounts or changing underwriting or anything like that. It's coming from driving those very long term loyal customers to visit more often and spend a bit more on each visit. So that continues to work out well. The pipeline, we expect another year of $2 billion in new vintages. We have a bunch that have been signed, haven't been released and will be released over the next couple of quarters. So the pipeline looks good. 
And as we move to Epsilon on the next page, that's where we run into probably, if you were to ask me, about where the concern is for the year. It's certainly not on the credit side. It's certainly not on the Canadian side. It's certainly not on the technology and data and digital sides of Epsilon Conversant. We are focused, however, on some weakness on the agency side, which is about 1/4 of Epsilon Conversant. And what we saw there was another general pullback in a number of verticals. And we're going to watch that carefully, as Charles said. We don't know whether it's just a result of CMOs taking a breather in the first quarter given the turmoil or whether that's more structural. In any event, if it is structural, we will make sure that earnings will remain on track, which means we'd have to focus on the expense side. 
But we don't know right now, and we're not going to need your opinion at this point. 
On the other side of it, the digital and technology platform stuff, up 8%. That's 3 quarters of Epsilon Conversant. And we continue to see very, very strong take up in terms of the data-driven targeted display offerings from Conversant. The number of wins that we're seeing right now are already half [ph] of what they were for the entire year last year. And then from an expense perspective and flexibly perspective, our India [ph] office is up and running. And we're hopefully continuing to staff that up as the year progresses, the metal finally beginning to move the needle on the expense side towards the latter part of the year. 
LoyaltyOne, I think Bryan covered that. Obviously, BrandLoyalty is a very choppy business. It had a -- frankly a little bit better Q1 from the EBITDA perspective than we have initially talked about. But recall last year, Q1 was when revenue was up 100%. So it was then down in Q2. This year, it will be more of the reverse where you'll have a very strong Q2 for BrandLoyalty, and it's all driven by when the grosses have decided to put their programs on the calendar.
Bryan have talked about the BrandLoyalty expansion into North America. Canada is doing quite well and moving nicely towards our goal there. And the U.S. actually we're beginning to make some nice inroads there as well. So good news on that front. 
Again, the concern on the AIR MILES side in Canada was net issuance would fall off as consumer spend was weak. What we found was the reverse, which was issuance was very strong and specifically issuance from the financial services space, which had been lagging before actually came back quite strongly. So it looks like Canada is still alive and kicking and doing quite well.
Revenue and EBITDA, plus 4, plus 11, frankly on a constant currency basis was the best we've seen in years. And so it looks like the business up there is back in growth mode. 
Overall, for those of you who have covered ADS for a number of years, it's kind of a typical ADS quarter. You've got a bunch of things that went a little bit better than expected. You had some things that weren't worse than expected. And the end result is they kind of even out and we meet or we beat our guidance. And that's pretty much been on our track record for the last 15 years. We expect that to be the case going forward as well.
If you look at it in the Cards group, the yields were a little bit worse than we have anticipated, but losses were a little bit better. And then at Epsilon, at digital and tech platforms, remained on track. We talked about agency and media was a weak, That was offset by the fact that LoyaltyOne, that AIR MILES was better, our BrandLoyalty was tracking. So again, looking at us, you can pick and choose whatever data points you want. But at the end of the day, the pluses and minuses, hopefully, even out to get to a double-digit growth rate for the year. And as we turn to our full year guidance, that's exactly what we're saying. It's very straightforward. Now with Q1 behind us, we have even a higher level of confidence on how the rest of the year is going to play out. And we feel very comfortable reiterating our full year guidance of revenue of 7 [ph] 1 [ph], up 10% of earnings of 16 75 [ph], up 11%. And the nice thing about it is the slowest quarter is behind us. We're going to ramp up to high single digits in the second quarter, and then we'll do double-digit top and bottom Q3, double-digit top and bottom in Q4, and that will give us a nice jump off into 2017. Visibility is quite strong. 
Q2 guidance rests around $1.6 billion [ph], up 8%. And earnings, also up about 8%. i think those are good numbers to start the acceleration.
From a Card Services perspective, you'll see the principal loss rate forecast that we gave a while ago. And lo and behold, it seems to be playing out at that level, if not just a smidge better, which is good. We expect for the year Card Services to once again deliver double-digit growth in revenue and adjusted EBITDA net of funding. 
Yield compression, which I'm sure we'll get some questions on, will lessen each quarter as the year progresses, so that we wind up at the end of the year with a very modest impression, which is how we want to take it into '17. And then I always said the pipeline is very robust, and that will get into a little bit about our decisions around who to renew, when to renew, at what levels will we renew clients, given that there's a certain amount of capital we want to put into the business, but we want to maintain it sort of a 20 plus growth rate in the file, and that means maybe our capital is better spent on other areas and we don't renew certain folks. 
So that's where we are on Epsilon. We talked about digital and tech platforms are 3 cores of the business. We expect that to continue clipping along in the high single digits. The signings for the Conversant CRM vintage, if you recall last year, was about 30 wins and a very strong vintage signing of 80-ish plus. Once they fully pull up, we expect to lease that this year, if not a bit better, which will be great. And now the agency is we're going to watch it and we're going to see the people-intensive business. It's in about a quarter of Epsilon Conversant. From what we're seeing, it looks soft, but it looks already like it's lessening in terms of the softness as we progress into Q2 and the rest of the year.
Okay. Last slide full year. LoyaltyOne, BrandLoyalty, Q2 is the big one for them. So expect a very, very strong double-digit rev in EBITDA. And then in AIR MILES, we remain comfortable that issuance, which is the key metric there, that's how we get paid, is going to be about 4% for the year, which will drive on a constant currency basis low single-digit revs, and EBITDA full year, which again would fly in the face of sort of the weakening consumer in Canada.
Overall, as I mentioned, several moving pieces, but full year is shaping up nicely. We are seeing zero stress on the consumer side. We are not seeing weakness in Canada. So those 2 data points are consistent with last quarter and the quarter before that. I just would talk a little bit about the model itself for Alliance. From 2007 through 2015, we produced annual growth rates of 15% and 18% for revenue and earnings per share, respectively, every single year. And for '16 and '17, as losses normalize and with the huge growth in the file, we're setting aside reserves for future losses, which are essentially doing knocking that growth rate down a bit. But you're still looking at low end double-digit growth rates and top and bottom. So this year, we're looking at 10 [ph] and 11 [ph], and that includes some drag from FX. And then in '18, if, in fact we're right and these rates have stabilized, then there's no reason to doubt that it would snap right back to the prior model and need to have a reacceleration in the growth rate.
So if you look at long-term for the company, you're looking somewhere midteens to high teens rev and core EPS. Then when you're in a period of normalization and building reserves, you're probably looking at low end, top and bottom double digits. And then you snap back to sort of midteens when that normalizes. So overall, not too shabby as a model. You'll also find with us that we tend to have different levers in different businesses cycle up and down at different times. But overall, the model holds together quite nicely. 
For guidance on the last slide, we're keeping at the same, and we're not going to spend a lot of time going through the this and that's of how we get there. But it looks pretty solid at plus 10%, plus 11%. And that puts our organic growth rate actually quite a bit above our 3x GDP target. We look at cash flow, looks very nice. Very strong this year at $1.4 billion. And when it comes to FX and all that other stuff, we'll adjust when it becomes meaningful as the year plays out. But again, we're not going to be tweaking everything every quarter. We're going to try to get this thing going on a consolidated basis.
So that's all I have. Why don't we open it up for Q&A? Q&A. Operator?

componenttext: And retail. It was interesting, we also have a pullback in Q1. It looks like it's beginning to trickle back in as we start moving into Q2, but it's still a little bit soft, so we don't want to call it yet. But it seem like a lot of people just stepped on the brakes in Q1. So I just don't know what the others are seeing out there right now, Sanjay. But from us, it looks like Q1, people just pulled back. And then as we're looking at Q2, it looks like it's beginning to loosen up a little bit. And so if it continues to loosen up, we're not going to need to take any action. If it continues to stay soft like this, we're going to have to take some internal actions.

And then on the agency side, to your point, we're assuming in our guidance that it will be soft, but not nearly as soft as Q1.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this gets -- it's a good question. And we're kind of at the point now where we got the business growing. The files grown 25% a year, which is pretty much -- we don't want to drift much higher than that. But we're also finding that the pipeline, the n
componenttext: Yes, this gets -- it's a good question. And we're kind of at the point now where we got the business growing. The files grown 25% a year, which is pretty much -- we don't want to drift much higher than that. But we're also finding that the pipeline, the number of opportunities that are out there as people shift their dollars to the data-driven targeted spend. Frankly, there's a whole bunch of business out there. And there are times in the past where we've had some clients who decided not to pour all their energy and efforts into driving tender share growth and card growth. It usually comes with the change in management. Other times, it's a change in strategy. And normally, we just sort of said that's fine. We'll go with the flow. Right now, we're dealing with how do we allocate our capital? If we want to continue to grow the business, the other file, 20-plus percent for the year, how do we maintain the type of returns that we expect. And frankly, there are a couple of programs there that based upon, how do we say it? The comments being made about the dollars that folks are willing to put into it, and the direction of those businesses, it didn't look like the best use of our capital. And so we've reallocated that capital to a couple of wins that we think are, I think, more down the stairway for us. So it's a nice -- I'm trying the polite way of saying there's going to be sometimes where the capital is better used elsewhere, and this is one of those times. We've just never been capital constraint, but we're at a point now where the growth rate in the file is pretty much at our max level.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just quickly follow up on the Epsilon side. I mean can you give us a little more granularity first onto the strength of the tech and data side there? I know Conversant in the pipeline looks strong still. But I guess I just want to make sure it's su
componenttext: Let me just quickly follow up on the Epsilon side. I mean can you give us a little more granularity first onto the strength of the tech and data side there? I know Conversant in the pipeline looks strong still. But I guess I just want to make sure it's sustainable. And you're not seeing the same lines on the legacy side pull back any at all on the tech side I mean the growth hasn't shown that yet. And then can you give us a more color on the levers that you have capable of pulling from a cost standpoint at Epsilon that has to start next quarter, I guess how much room do we have? It seems like an area that you're trying to cut cost in the past and outsource in India, et cetera? And I want to see how much color on how much room there is.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean right now, what we're seeing is a continuation of a strong demand for the Digital Products at Conversant, specifically sort of the SKU level, data-driven targeted display offering. Very strong. In general, the more core Epsilon, Big Loyalty an
componenttext: Yes. I mean right now, what we're seeing is a continuation of a strong demand for the Digital Products at Conversant, specifically sort of the SKU level, data-driven targeted display offering. Very strong. In general, the more core Epsilon, Big Loyalty and customer data builds are strong and data offerings our strong. So a lot of -- all that heavy tech stuff demand continues to be strong and we expect that to continue for the year. On the agency side, look, we need to be very careful we don't knee-jerk this thing. If it's an air pocket, then great, and we're back in business. If it looks like it's softer than we expect, then it's a very project intensive, people-intensive business, we would have to move quickly to make sure that revenues and expenses sync up. But what we're seeing right now is the softness in Q1 is already lessening a bit as we move into Q2. So we're going to hold off knee-jerking this thing. And if, in fact, Q2 comes in very soft on the agency side, we'll still make our numbs for the company from a guidance perspective, for sure. But we'll have to take some expenses out to make sure we take our numbers for the year.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Maybe I just missed it, but in terms of 5%, what was your overall Epsilon outlook for the year now in terms of organic growth for that whole segment?

componenttext: What we talked about Epsilon is mid-single digit, less from top to bottom. I think we'll stay there.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Staying there? Okay, All right. Let me just shift in and then I'll turn it over to the queue. But on the Private Label, the Card Services side, I guess first on growth, do you agree -- I mean, cobranding is tougher now from a competitive standpoint. So ju
componenttext: Staying there? Okay, All right. Let me just shift in and then I'll turn it over to the queue. But on the Private Label, the Card Services side, I guess first on growth, do you agree -- I mean, cobranding is tougher now from a competitive standpoint. So just revisiting the addressable market in terms of opportunities, obviously given your -- I think this is the first time I'll ever hear you guys talk about the core 4 [ph] portfolios based on better opportunities and the profitability elsewhere. But either way, I guess just revisiting the addressable market will be helpful given that it's more Private Label focused than cobranding now. And on that note, the yield compression is a combination of things, that you guys mentioned automated payments and new vintages but also core branding. with all of those things anniversarying and cobranding potentially moving lower now as a potential mix, should the yield be potentially rise in '17 or will it be stable?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the yield will be relatively stable in '17, exactly to your point. As we're burning through these compression issues and something to anniversary. And to your point exactly, a little less emphasis on the cobrand side. You won't have that sort of l
componenttext: I think the yield will be relatively stable in '17, exactly to your point. As we're burning through these compression issues and something to anniversary. And to your point exactly, a little less emphasis on the cobrand side. You won't have that sort of large compression that you've seen in the last couple of years, 100 basis points or so on the yield side and be significantly less than that. And that has to do again with we're looking to optimize the portfolio, which means that if this part of the cycle, you've got an awful lot of mouths to feed when it comes to co-brand, that it isn't quite as exciting to us at this point in the cycle. We've seen this play out before. So we're looking to optimize the file, continue the growth at 20-plus-percent, and keep the compression much more modest on a go-forward basis. And based on the pipeline and what we're signing, what you see we'll release over this year, we feel pretty good in it.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: We came in a little bit better in Q1. I think you'll see we could come in a little bit better in Q2 and Q3. In terms of midteens, it's growing better by 10 bps in the quarter, so know its timing. But I'd say we're tracking to the 5 [ph] loss rate that we've given as guidance.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I'd say we're still around 80 [ph], 20 [ph], 80% [ph] Private Label, 20% cobrand. To Ed's point before, we're doing less cobrand as where the most of the competition is and we're focused more on Private Label. You know us, Private Label is our secret sauce. That's where we have all the expertise. And so you'll see more growth coming there which long-term should benefit the yields going back to Darin's question before.

componenttext: Hey Ed and Charles, just the additional buybacks in your guidance, you bought back about 400 [ph] million, you said you have 500 [ph] million, and I think you expect to buy back closer to 800 [ph] million to 1 [ph] billion?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: okay. Then on the tender share improvement, the 80% for mature accounts, it's very helpful. But is that piece being driven by increasing credit lines for those individuals that are using the line? And obviously since they're mature accounts, I'm sure they
componenttext: okay. Then on the tender share improvement, the 80% for mature accounts, it's very helpful. But is that piece being driven by increasing credit lines for those individuals that are using the line? And obviously since they're mature accounts, I'm sure they're performing well, credit wise?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it's -- we're not coughing up lines. We never really had an issue of open to buy. I think Charles knows it better than I did, we have a $500 [ph] balance, we might have an $800 [ph] line. So there's plenty of room on the open to buy and we re
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's -- we're not coughing up lines. We never really had an issue of open to buy. I think Charles knows it better than I did, we have a $500 [ph] balance, we might have an $800 [ph] line. So there's plenty of room on the open to buy and we rescore all 40 million accounts every quarter. So it's not a credit line issue. It's more of, if I have an 800 [ph] line and a 500 [ph] balance and I'm growing it normally 5% a year, how do I get it to 7% or 8%? And that's basically the whole tender share again, which is how do I get her to make one more visit if they're not visiting the store itself. A lot of our tender share gains, I'd say the bulk of it is coming through online sales. We'll be reach out to her and make some type of compelling offer to her and she'd go online and buy it. A lot of this to use the lingo, she's snacking online, meaning that we're seeing a lot of incremental purchases that are relatively small in size, but they're happening very frequently.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then last question, on the agency business, on the Epsilon business, is that -- I mean, have you lost -- is this just pulled back by client? Have you lost some clients? Are you losing share of a client to another competitor or piece? So what's
componenttext: Great. And then last question, on the agency business, on the Epsilon business, is that -- I mean, have you lost -- is this just pulled back by client? Have you lost some clients? Are you losing share of a client to another competitor or piece? So what's going on there? I don't think the industry has pulled back as much as we saw in your business in the first quarter. And who are you primarily competing with today in these sectors?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question. We don't -- 1 quarter doesn't a trend make. So it's still up in the air in terms of what exactly. What we did see was we saw project business basically dry out in the first quarter. But we accounted on and as a result, the business w
componenttext: It's a good question. We don't -- 1 quarter doesn't a trend make. So it's still up in the air in terms of what exactly. What we did see was we saw project business basically dry out in the first quarter. But we accounted on and as a result, the business we needed to close to make agency hit Q1 didn't happen. Now are those projects beginning to drift back in? It looks like they're slowly drifting back in. So that's all we know at this point.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Who are you seeing as your -- by sector or agency versus tech, would you point out as your 2 or 3 largest and toughest competitors?
componenttext: Who are you seeing as your -- by sector or agency versus tech, would you point out as your 2 or 3 largest and toughest competitors?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's all over the board in terms of when it's pure agency, you can have the big Madison Avenue players involved there. You can have some of the other digital smaller agencies involved there. But yes, for the most part what we do is we like to link
componenttext: I think it's all over the board in terms of when it's pure agency, you can have the big Madison Avenue players involved there. You can have some of the other digital smaller agencies involved there. But yes, for the most part what we do is we like to link the agency as sort of the tip of the arrow to get in the door with CMO to flow through to the big, heavy duty high visibility tech platforms that we built from them. The project base stuff on the agency side, as you can tell is the stuff that we can joke around quite a bit on a quarterly basis. So, that's sort of -- we're seeing the big tech platforms continue to be built. And it's just these projects from an agency side that we saw softness in Q1. So just don't want to get out in front of this thing and start, oh my gosh, we've got long-term weakness in the agency when it could very well just be a 1 quarter phenomenon.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bob, the only thing I would add is that it's not a case where we're losing client. It's not a number of clients pursuing risk or sell less spend. So in the first quarter, we really felt that spend going back to Ed's point on a project basis, CMO cut th
componenttext: So Bob, the only thing I would add is that it's not a case where we're losing client. It's not a number of clients pursuing risk or sell less spend. So in the first quarter, we really felt that spend going back to Ed's point on a project basis, CMO cut the budgets with us for whatever reason.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey, and he's with SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey, and he's with SunTrust.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, I guess I want to ask a big picture strategic question with regard to Epsilon. Is there -- as you think about agency, irrespective sort of the quarterly volatility in that business, is there still the same sort of competitive strategic rationale for h
componenttext: Ed, I guess I want to ask a big picture strategic question with regard to Epsilon. Is there -- as you think about agency, irrespective sort of the quarterly volatility in that business, is there still the same sort of competitive strategic rationale for having the agency as part of Epsilon as you might have thought there was 5 years ago? Has your thinking changed on that at all?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's absolutely critical that we have that skill set, because that's the skill set that can get in the door, have the conversation with the CMO. And that will then lead to the pull through the big client database with the big loyalty platform
componenttext: No, I think it's absolutely critical that we have that skill set, because that's the skill set that can get in the door, have the conversation with the CMO. And that will then lead to the pull through the big client database with the big loyalty platform builds, the big CRM business, the Conversant. So no, I think the skill set there is critical in order to pull through for the other parts of Epsilon. it's almost like even though if it's a bit soft this quarter, my view is if you take it away, what you're going to wind out is you're going to cut the head off the rest of the big tech pull-throes at the rest of Epsilon and the whole thing will eventually slow down.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there -- with regard to, again agency, is there a customer concentration issue you think within that business? Is that part of the reason we see the volatility? Is there anything else we can do?
componenttext: Is there -- with regard to, again agency, is there a customer concentration issue you think within that business? Is that part of the reason we see the volatility? Is there anything else we can do?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is part of it, Andrew. If you look our biggest clients in Epsilon are all on the agency side of the business. So when they pull back on an any project or maybe not supporting us this particular offering, they can move the needle quickly. And being proj
componenttext: It is part of it, Andrew. If you look our biggest clients in Epsilon are all on the agency side of the business. So when they pull back on an any project or maybe not supporting us this particular offering, they can move the needle quickly. And being project based, they can do volatility in through the quarter. Quite a bit for the year, they can pretty well estimate what they're going to do. But they can basically open up it quite quickly based on what they wanted to do with our marketing spend. And so what we said in Q1 basically close this ticket and we think that they will open up as the year progresses and sounding alarm bells. But it is big companies, big budgets and they can flex it quite quickly.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then quickly, with regard to your outlook for what maybe a loss rate plateau in '18 and beyond, can you dig a little bit into the rationale and thought process that gives you confidence that you might see something that's pretty unprecedented hi
componenttext: Okay. And then quickly, with regard to your outlook for what maybe a loss rate plateau in '18 and beyond, can you dig a little bit into the rationale and thought process that gives you confidence that you might see something that's pretty unprecedented historically in terms of stable charge-offs?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you look at it, it's a great question. The fact that as we talked about the bulk of our growth, the 10% in the core growth is really coming from accounts that are very mature, have been well seasoned, well pass the peak charge-offs cycle.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at it, it's a great question. The fact that as we talked about the bulk of our growth, the 10% in the core growth is really coming from accounts that are very mature, have been well seasoned, well pass the peak charge-offs cycle. We are normalizing the loss rate. I think may be 2 more staff might be helpful, which is look before the Great Recession, our normalized loss rate was 6.5%. We're seeing it's 5.5% now. Why is that? Why are we comfortable that that's our long term run rate? And that's what we're normalizing towards. Probably a couple of interesting stats there. One is the new mix of co-brand which carries a higher scoring customer as well as some of the higher end type retailers that have joined us, we're attracting cardholders that tend to skew a little bit higher on the credit spectrum. So for example, if you were to compare all of our active account today versus 2007, the scores today on average are higher than they were in 2007, even with some of a lot of the accounts that we've added recently. So from an active account basis, the average score is higher. Also if you look at it from a balanced perspective, the average score per balance today is higher than it was in 2007. And so you put those 2 together and that's how you get to -- we're not going to normalize out of 6.5%, we're going to normalize out of 5.5%. But look, it's not like we're trying to keep it lower. The fact is you give up some yields by not being at higher loss rates. So I'm not sure it's a strategy of ours to keep it at 5.5%. It's just the way the file is playing out right now.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Ashish Sabadra with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Ashish Sabadra with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on the agency weakness here. So the agency weakness as well as core Epsilon. I'm just wondering the 20% decline you seen is consistent across both those segments? And then Charles, you mentioned that there is inter-quarter volatilit
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the agency weakness here. So the agency weakness as well as core Epsilon. I'm just wondering the 20% decline you seen is consistent across both those segments? And then Charles, you mentioned that there is inter-quarter volatility there depending on the projects. Is there something you can to strategically going forward to lower that volatility? Or is it just that as it continues to grow faster, it will be a bigger portion of the revenues? I'm just wondering, how should we think about the volatility coming down agency because it has been volatile over the last several quarters now?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're right, Ashish, we're going to have to grow the part of the business quicker that's just frankly where it's going to be. Agency in a good year is going to grow 3%, technology in a good year is going to grow 10 [ph] plus. So from a mixed standpoint,
componenttext: You're right, Ashish, we're going to have to grow the part of the business quicker that's just frankly where it's going to be. Agency in a good year is going to grow 3%, technology in a good year is going to grow 10 [ph] plus. So from a mixed standpoint, you basically take some of the volatility away from that. If you look at the breakdown, it was weakness in both categories. We saw weakness in traditional agency for Epsilon where we saw weakness in across many verticals. I couldn't pinpoint any one client because it was broad-based. On the Conversant side, on the traditional display, we've definitely seen pure people trying to use our private exchange. You've got the big agencies trying to push the client into their own trading platforms. So regardless of the quality, the impressions we can provide, they're trying to stuff it through the old system, we saw a general pull back there. So that was a little bit unexpected. So I'd say it was both sides of it. We do think we'll get some stability as the year goes on, but there's really, going back to Ed's point, anything particularly we can point to aside from we see a soft spend in Q1.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just quickly on the margins for the Epsilon business. You highlighted a couple of reasons for the margins being lower, but how should we think about margins going forward? Technically, if agency attempts to be a lower margin, tech was a higher margi
componenttext: Okay. Just quickly on the margins for the Epsilon business. You highlighted a couple of reasons for the margins being lower, but how should we think about margins going forward? Technically, if agency attempts to be a lower margin, tech was a higher margin business and tech is growing faster, you would expect the margins go up going forward. So wanted to better understand how should we think about the dynamics for Epsilon margins over the next several quarters but also the longer-term?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the way you look at it is basically, you're right. Agency grows slower. It's the lower EBITDA margin, your technology will grow quicker. It's the highest EBITDA margins. So from a pure mix standpoint you should get some EBITDA margin expansion this yea
componenttext: So the way you look at it is basically, you're right. Agency grows slower. It's the lower EBITDA margin, your technology will grow quicker. It's the highest EBITDA margins. So from a pure mix standpoint you should get some EBITDA margin expansion this year and in the future. Clearly, we'll have to look at the agency and play through if its a short-term hiccup or air pocket as I said before, or it's the case where we have to structurally cut back on cost to get our margins back where they need to be. That's a little bit of the unknown at this point. For the long-term, I would expect the margin to expand slightly based on mix.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And one final question on the gross yield compression. So the rate fees have been -- the lower rate fees have been weighing on because it helps you, or it's reflective of the better consumer environment. But just how should we think a
componenttext: That's very helpful. And one final question on the gross yield compression. So the rate fees have been -- the lower rate fees have been weighing on because it helps you, or it's reflective of the better consumer environment. But just how should we think about that compression, like how much visibility how much confidence do you have that it comes up during the second half and going into '17?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have very good visibility into this as we go into the second half. A large chunk of it, probably half of it, relates to what I call consumer-friendly programs, which I probably should find. It basically is we look at all of our practices, and basi
componenttext: Yes. We have very good visibility into this as we go into the second half. A large chunk of it, probably half of it, relates to what I call consumer-friendly programs, which I probably should find. It basically is we look at all of our practices, and basically said how do we continue to see the premium provider in the marketplace, the most customer friendly provider in the marketplace as we continue to ramp up? And so there's a bunch of things that we put in place as we went into back capital of last year. So for example, it doesn't seem like a lot, but it does move the needle in terms of if someone gets paid on the 15th of each month, but their balance is due on the 13th, well that doesn't work out all that well sometimes. So what we've done is we've given everyone the right to move their due date to later on in the month, if they wanted to. And that, again, it doesn't seem like much, but it actually does affect the late fees. But at the same time, and also helps our OpEx as you see with the leverage because we have much lower talk time of people coming off, calling on, saying hey, we need a couple more days. So you have that. You have people who are calling in where there used to be a fee if you're paying by the phone. We decided that wasn't best practices. We took that out as well. And so we just took a number of things out of the system that frankly cost more grief than they added. We got a lot of it back in lower OpEx in terms of lower talk time and everything else and we have a much happier client and customer base. And so I think that's sort of what it is. None of it was dictated by any regulatory authority. It was something we proactively went out and just did. We think we're taking the hit now for it, and seeing it anniversary in the back half is probably the best thing to do. Hopefully, that will pay dividends down the line.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your final question comes from David Scharf with JMP Securities.
componenttext: And your final question comes from David Scharf with JMP Securities.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize in advance, Ed, if it's sort of a repeat of some that have been asked, but I just want a clarification. On the agency side, can you give us a sense for how much of business, for agency, is so-called project based versus, I guess, work that you
componenttext: I apologize in advance, Ed, if it's sort of a repeat of some that have been asked, but I just want a clarification. On the agency side, can you give us a sense for how much of business, for agency, is so-called project based versus, I guess, work that you would deem to be well not an annuity, pretty reliable and recurring? Obviously its all based on CMO budget. But is the vast majority of the business, things that you would deem to be, quarter-by-quarter project is where there isn't necessarily great visibility?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Definitely on the Epsilon side of it, that's the case, whereas we're you got 1 or 2 year contracts but it's project to project. On the Conversant side, it's going to be more volume driven because its basically side display. So basically, you got a lot of
componenttext: Definitely on the Epsilon side of it, that's the case, whereas we're you got 1 or 2 year contracts but it's project to project. On the Conversant side, it's going to be more volume driven because its basically side display. So basically, you got a lot of unpredictably when you get to agency you can have a longer-term contract but it's flexed based on volume. Predicting what it's going to be on a quarter-to-quarter basis it's just a difficult thing to do, David.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. And when we think about the cost structure, and obviously, the agency business has always had the least amount of operating leverage, given its people intensive. But can you -- you've talked about in the disclosure that agency is roughly m
componenttext: Got it, got it. And when we think about the cost structure, and obviously, the agency business has always had the least amount of operating leverage, given its people intensive. But can you -- you've talked about in the disclosure that agency is roughly maybe 1/4 of the Epsilon segment, the traditional Aspen business plus Conversant. But from the standpoint of the percentage of fixed cost, how should we think about it?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say your premise is right, David. It is a higher fixed cost of business. It's more of a people-driven business, so variability is pretty low. Part of the reason why you saw that our EBITDA was down in the quarter because the revenue was down on the ag
componenttext: I'd say your premise is right, David. It is a higher fixed cost of business. It's more of a people-driven business, so variability is pretty low. Part of the reason why you saw that our EBITDA was down in the quarter because the revenue was down on the agency and it reflects very much. So you're right, I don't have an exact percentage, but you can assume that it's our highest fixed cost business will be within agency. So if we see a structural issue in the market then we'll have to go through and address the fixed cost and we need to do so pretty quickly if we need to.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if we think about a description of a lessening degree of revenue decline in Q2, I mean 23% is a big number. I mean should we be thinking 15% to 20% down, or more closer to 10%? Just trying to get a little bit of context.
componenttext: Okay. And if we think about a description of a lessening degree of revenue decline in Q2, I mean 23% is a big number. I mean should we be thinking 15% to 20% down, or more closer to 10%? Just trying to get a little bit of context.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think we're in a position to really say at this point on as to what it's going to be. We do feel good it's going to get better with a difficult comp in Q1, so we know it's going to be less in Q2. But at this stage, it would be very difficult
componenttext: Yes. I don't think we're in a position to really say at this point on as to what it's going to be. We do feel good it's going to get better with a difficult comp in Q1, so we know it's going to be less in Q2. But at this stage, it would be very difficult for me to quantify it, Q2, Q3, Q4. As you know, David, we look at our guidance in total, not in any single piece. So just like in the first quarter, we had over performance in some areas and weakness in other. We have looked for the year to be in the same way. So it's very difficult for me to quantify that for you, David.

componenttext: I'd say it's a little bit of both. You do have some new wins coming through and we'll focus on that during the course of the year. I know I was told over and over we're heading into recession quite quickly in the U.S., So I think many people listen to the rhetoric. And I think it's project based discretionary based marketing, I think we pulled back a little bit in Q1.
