headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Alliance Data First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In order to view the company's presentation on their website, please remember to turn off your pop-up blocker on your computer. It is now
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Alliance Data First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In order to view the company's presentation on their website, please remember to turn off your pop-up blocker on your computer. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Steve Calk of FTI Consulting. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. By now you should have received a copy of the company's first quarter 2016 earnings release. If you have not, please call FTI Consulting at (212) 850-5721. On the call today, we have Ed Heffernan, President and Chief Executive Offic
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. By now you should have received a copy of the company's first quarter 2016 earnings release. If you have not, please call FTI Consulting at (212) 850-5721. 
On the call today, we have Ed Heffernan, President and Chief Executive Officer of Alliance Data; Charles Horn, Chief Financial Officer of Alliance Data; and Bryan Pearson, President and Chief Executive Officer of LoyaltyOne. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that some of the comments made on today's call and some of the responses to your questions may contain forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to the risks and uncertainties described in the company's earnings release and other filings with the SEC. Alliance Data has no obligation to update the information presented on the call. 
Also on today's call, our speakers will reference certain non-GAAP financial measures, which we believe will provide useful information for investors. Reconciliation of those measures to GAAP will be posted on the Investor Relations website at www.alliancedata.com.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Ed Heffernan. Ed?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. With me today, as mentioned, is Charles Horn, our CFO; and Bryan Pearson, Head of our LoyaltyOne business, and that includes both the AIR MILES business in Canada as well as the BrandLoyalty business headquartered out of the Netherlands. Ch
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. With me today, as mentioned, is Charles Horn, our CFO; and Bryan Pearson, Head of our LoyaltyOne business, and that includes both the AIR MILES business in Canada as well as the BrandLoyalty business headquartered out of the Netherlands. Charles will update you on the quarterly results. Bryan will give you some color into the various businesses at LoyaltyOne, and I'll wrap it up with the score card Q1 results as well as my outlook for full year 2016. Based on past comments, we're going to move with pace, so we can have more time for questions at the end. Take it away, Charles.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Turning to Slide 2, I will talk about the first quarter results, and they were pretty much as we expected, with revenue up 5% to $1.68 billion and core EPS up 5% at $3.84. It was a quarter with several positives but also a few negatives that t
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed. Turning to Slide 2, I will talk about the first quarter results, and they were pretty much as we expected, with revenue up 5% to $1.68 billion and core EPS up 5% at $3.84. It was a quarter with several positives but also a few negatives that tempered overall results. One of the negatives, foreign exchange rates, reduced both revenue and core EPS by about 2 points for the first quarter. The good news is that FX rates seem to have stabilized and the drag could drop to near zero in the back half of 2016.
Looking forward, we expect growth in each quarter to accelerate as 2016 progresses. Revenue growth of 5% in Q1 is expected to increase to 8% in Q2 and then double-digit growth in Q3 and Q4. Adjusted EBITDA and core EPS are expected to follow a similar trend. 
Now why do we believe this? Putting aside improving foreign-exchange comparables, there are several reasons. First, gross yield compression at Card Services should lessen each quarter as we anniversary several program changes made last year. Second, loss rates were expected to drift downward from first quarter highs. Third, BrandLoyalty has passed its most difficult comparable. If you remember in the first quarter 2015, the revenue was up over 100% on a constant currency basis. 
Lastly, Epsilon's agency weakness should lessen, coupled with a record year-end backlog for second half delivery. During the quarter, we acquired 2 million shares under our repurchase program for approximately $440 million. The buyback program remains our top capital allocation priority, and we expect will be executed somewhat ratably over the remainder of 2016. Essentially, we will look to deploy our free cash flow, while maintaining the leverage ratio of less than 3x.
With that, let's go to the next slide and Bryan will walk you through the Q1 results.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charles. LoyaltyOne had a better-than-expected quarter as revenue decreased 2% to $381 million, but adjusted EBITDA increased 10% to $85 million on a constant currency basis. Breaking it down further, at AIR MILES our revenue increased 4% and adju
componenttext:
Thanks, Charles. LoyaltyOne had a better-than-expected quarter as revenue decreased 2% to $381 million, but adjusted EBITDA increased 10% to $85 million on a constant currency basis. Breaking it down further, at AIR MILES our revenue increased 4% and adjusted EBITDA increased a robust 11% on a constant currency basis, and that was driven by a favorable issuance mix and prudent cost controls. 
As expected at BrandLoyalty, revenue was down 9% on a constant currency basis due to program timing differences. Encouragingly, adjusted EBITDA increased 9% on a constant currency basis due to higher margin programs that were driving a 300 basis points expansion in adjusted EBITDA margins.
AIR MILES issued increased a robust 5% or 57 million miles over the same quarter from last year. Issuance was particularly strong with our financial vertical as we continue to convert BMO MasterCard holders through the Premium World Elite card that has a more compelling consumer proposition and a higher AIR MILES earn offer. This strong growth was achieved despite economic uncertainty in Western Canada that's the result of the declining global oil prices that has been negatively impacting activity at our grocery partners, and also the suspension of point issuance on prescriptions in British Columbia.
Looking ahead, we anticipate a 2% decline in issuance growth through the second quarter due to reduced promotional activity and the onetime conversion of the Sobeys legacy program that happened in 2015, which of course would not be repeated.
As we have stated previously, quarterly results can vary based on the timing of promotional activity, but our target remains a full year issuance growth of mid-single digits. 
AIR MILES redeemed increased 6% compared to the first quarter of 2015, with our AIR MILES cash program, that the instant reward option, driving approximately half of the increase as its liquidity feature resonates with collectors in the current macro environment.
For the full year, we anticipate redemption growth to be in line with issuance growth. 
For the year, we anticipate full year constant currency revenue and adjusted EBITDA growth for AIR MILES to be in the mid-single-digit range as well.
Now turning to BrandLoyalty. We anticipate a very strong second quarter whereby revenue could be up as much as 50% on a constant currency basis. On the North American expansion front, BrandLoyalty continues to increase its presence in Canada, with sticks promotions that have been planned for 2016, and this represents a significant increase in sales over last year.
In addition, we launched our first pilot in the U.S. late in the first quarter. We were pleased with the results to date and look forward to additional programs in this market. The full year expectation for BrandLoyalty continues to be mid-teens growth in both revenue and adjusted EBITDA as compared to 2015 on a constant currency basis.
Lastly, let me update you on Dotz and Precima. Starting with Dotz, our Brazilian coalition program, where we continue to see steady growth in our collector base to over 18 million currently. In November of last year, Dotz successfully launched the coalition program in Rio de Janeiro with the Cencosud grocery banner called Prezunic as a key partner.
Cencosud is the third-largest grocer in Brazil and collector reception has been positive, with over 1 million collectors now enrolled and active in Rio. 
Precima, our data analytics unit, continues to fire on all cylinders, recently signing a deal with Morrisons, one of the UK's top 4 grocers, where we will apply data intelligence and shopper insights to help Morrisons more effectively apply their customer-centric retailing approach.
In closing, LoyaltyOne achieve solid first quarter results with a positive outlook for the remainder of 2016. I'd like to take this opportunity to congratulate the entire team on a great quarter and look forward to their commitment to our valued clients and to LoyaltyOne. Awesome job, everyone. I guess, back to you, Charles.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan. Let's turn to Slide 4. Epsilon's revenue decreased 2% to $493 million and adjusted EBITDA decreased 22% to $81 million for the first quarter of 2016. Results in this segment were mixed at 3/4 of the business, digital and technology platform
componenttext:
Thanks, Bryan. Let's turn to Slide 4. Epsilon's revenue decreased 2% to $493 million and adjusted EBITDA decreased 22% to $81 million for the first quarter of 2016. Results in this segment were mixed at 3/4 of the business, digital and technology platforms grew a best 8% during the quarter, while the remaining 1/4, agency reforms, where the revenues declined by 23% versus the first quarter 2015. Adjusted EBITDA decreased $23 million from the first quarter of 2015, primarily due to higher payroll costs, staffing levels increased in anticipation of revenue that is yet to occur.
Before we dive into the individual portions, you see that we have a new reporting format here. We thought that the old formats where we just talked about database and data and support really is not reflective of the way we go to business these days. Specifically, is the broad portfolio of off-line, online services Epsilon delivers our package for bundled, omnichannel solutions, it just doesn't make sense for us to give it to you in that format. So what we've done is we put this together. We're going to highlight 2 categories that represent the underlying services and assets deployed to serve our clients. 
The first category, digital and technology platforms, consists of businesses which is primarily derived from revenues tied to one of the many core data and our technology platforms that Epsilon and Conversant manage. These platforms are used to house and manage data in real-time, to analyze and model data, and to automate usage of that data across a variety of channels, whether it be through a loyalty program within e-mail communication or an online message delivered on mobile or desktop devices.
The remainder of the business, agency media and services, consist of services which are primarily focused on supporting the agency sector. Both media services delivered to agencies on behalf of their clients as well as agency engagements in which Epsilon acts as the primary agency directly on behalf of its clients.
Now let's turn to the digital and technology portion of this segment, where quarterly revenue grew by $28 million year-over-year or about 8% mostly due to continued success of the cross-sell efforts and on-boarding of the strong CRM backlog within Conversant. The products offered within the CRM business continue to resonate with both new and existing clients, as 50 new contracts have already been signed this year versus 30, all of last year. The 2016 vintage thus far includes GNC, Brooks Brothers, Coach and Sears is a great follow-up to last year's efforts. These clients along with others such as Walgreens, are connecting with real people as a result of combining an automized first party with third-party data and $80 billion daily online interactions to develop a persistent consumer ID.
Moving on to agency media and services, revenue declined 23% from the first quarter of 2015. For Epsilon's traditional agency business, we saw broad-based weakness, especially in the telco, CPG and retail verticals. In addition, the agency business are conversant which is the nondata-driven traditional display business was down as large agencies push more programmatic buying through their internal trading platforms versus using third-party DSPs.
We don't know if this bubble is a bubble with an agency or more structural. It needs to play out as the year progresses. If it's structural, we have to be more aggressive on going after cost cuts to maintain our earnings. Although it will likely continue to see volatility within the agency on a quarterly basis, it is a key part of the CMO selling process which attracts more broad and less IT-centric relationships.
Now let's go over to the next slide and talk about Card Services. Card Services delivered strong financial results, achieving a 17th consecutive quarter of double-digit revenue growth. Revenue increased 17% for the first quarter of 2016, driven by 27% increase in average receivables. Adjusted EBITDA net grew 9%, dampened slightly by the provision builds. Importantly, principal loss rates were 5.2% for the quarter, 10 basis points better than our original guidance.
Focusing on the key drivers for our growth. Credit sales increased a healthy 25%, driven by our proven ability to grow customer loyalty for both our long standing and through its brand partners as well as favorable weather and an early Easter. Our core business, brand partners with us from 4 years or more, continues to contribute roughly half of our credit sales growth. Importantly, we continue to grow tender share, up over 200 basis points for the first quarter by leveraging our large understanding of our brands along with the deep data analytics we bring to bear.
Most of the tender share pickup is being driven by card members, who have been engage with their card for multiple years, not from new accounts. In other words, these are tenured cardmembers with a proven spending and payment history and they are demonstrating increased spend with the brands they love. This is a testament to the power of our customized marketing programs and the value they deliver to our long-standing partners. It's also a key differentiator and critical element in our ability to welcome new partners.
Looking at the remaining drivers of our performance, we talked about revenue grew 17% driven by the strong AR growth. Importantly, we really have strong operating expense leverage as we are able to drop our expense ratio by 70 bps for the quarter. 
As expected, gross yields are experiencing some compression driven primarily by brand mix, accounting for acquired files and lower late fees as we obtain several declines for several months in our first stage delinquency bucket. This pressure is predominantly in the first half of the year, and we expect yields to normalize as we anniversary these items.
Managing losses was key in the first quarter, and we exceeded guidance previously outlined. Losses, delinquency levels and funding costs were all in line with both expectations and seasonal trends. During the quarter, we decided not to renew 2 card programs for renewal at year-end. The related receivables net of the allowance for loan loss have been reclassified to assets held for sale at March 31, 2016. Accordingly, $430 million has been removed from card receivables and $15 million has been removed from the allowance for loan loss. 
Our reserve for loan losses was 5.7% of receivables at March 31, 2016, up from 5.5% at December 31, 2015. Reserve dollars dropped by $15 million from December 31, due to the reclassification previously discussed. 
In closing for Card Services, we delivered another stellar quarter, with all the key metrics outpacing the industry and consistent with our expectations. We are positioned for another record year in line with our strategy of 20% plus credit sales and AR growth, leveraging both organic growth and new partnerships.
With that, I'll turn it over to Ed.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, guys. When we turn to first quarter scorecard and the goal, of course, is to have more greens than yellows and reds, and right now, we're tracking with 30 being green. I would say in terms of Q1 a couple of general comments, one is, as Char
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, guys. When we turn to first quarter scorecard and the goal, of course, is to have more greens than yellows and reds, and right now, we're tracking with 30 being green. I would say in terms of Q1 a couple of general comments, one is, as Charles mentioned, this was obviously our toughest quarter. Comp versus last year was very difficult. And putting in a plus 5 top, plus 5 earnings, was right on the money of what we wanted to do. And our view into the rest of the year looks solid. So it's good to get that behind us.
Also, you'll find that it was kind of a mixed bag in terms of what it got us from A to B. But at the end, the pluses sort of outweighed the minuses and we got where we wanted to be.
As we move into the second quarter and the rest of the year, things are accelerating nicely. We have a good line of sight into the rest of the year. From our first quarter perspective, consolidated, we came right in where we said in terms of guidance at about $1.7 billion top and about $384 million on earnings. That was -- that included getting hit on the FX side, with about $26 million in top and about $0.05 on earnings from FX, which, if it holds, will fortunately start to anniversary as we move into the back half. 
We talked about the toughest comp of the year's now behind us, and we were pretty active in the buyback, taking in a bunch of shares which we thought were pretty cheap.
So overall consolidated, we got where we wanted to be and remain on track for the year in Card Services. Just the highlights, of course, the portfolio continues to grow very quickly, with over 20% growth, revenue in the high teens. And then obviously, due to the fact that we're growing so quickly, we need to obviously set up reserves and that tends to be a damper on EBITDA. Nonetheless, they did grow 9%. 
Yields gets the yellow. It was a little over 200 basis points due to multiple factors that we can talk about. Again, the good news there is that it's already beginning to burn away, and we expect less compression as each quarter goes by for the year, and we have pretty good visibility into that as well, so more of a Q1 issue. 
The loss rate, we spent the first 3 months of the year here, dealing with 2 questions that people were spooked about. The first being credit quality, and the second being Canada going into a depression. And what's interesting is those are the 2 items that probably performed best during the quarter. Credit quality actually came in a little bit better than we had anticipated. We now expect it to drift downwards as the year progresses from a seasonally high Q1. And similar to what we said 3 months ago, we'll say the same thing now. We check with our collectors and everyone else. There is 0 pressure that we're seeing coming in that would suggest that there's any type of stress on the consumer at this point. So we're just not seeing it. We didn't see it before. And again, we're just normalizing the loss rates in the file, which right now we're tracking nicely to that.
I will emphasize the next point which is tender share. That's often lost in all these discussions about growth and are you growing too fast, too slowly, how are you growing? Is it good quality, bad quality and all that other stuff. Tender share is up 200 basis points, which means if 30% of the sales at a retailer were on our card a year ago, now it's 32%. And that is not being moved by putting on a bunch of new accounts. And in fact, what it essentially means is that when the retailers growing 2%, 3%, we're growing 10%. And so the first 10 points of portfolio growth are coming from a deeper penetration of that retailer sales base. And the next bullet point to me really brings it home that 80% of this tender share gained, they're coming from the mature accounts. They're coming from accounts that have been with us for 20, 24 months or more, which means they passed the peak sort of loss point, and they're very mature. And our ability to get in there and motivate incremental spend is what it's all about. And that's the data-driven targeted marketing. And I think that's probably the most important takeaway is that this is not coming from tossing on a whole bunch of new accounts or changing, underwriting or anything like that. It's coming from driving those very long-term loyal customers to visit more often and spend a bit more on each visit. So that continues to work out well. The pipeline, we expect another year of $2 billion in new vintages. We have a bunch that have been signed, haven't been released and they will be released over the next couple of quarters. So the pipeline looks good. 
And as we move to Epsilon on the next page, that's where we run into probably, if you were to ask me, about where the concern is for the year. It's certainly not on the credit side. It's certainly not on the Canadian side. It's certainly not on the technology and data and digital sides of Epsilon Conversant. We are focused, however, on some weakness on the agency side, which is about 1/4 of Epsilon Conversant. And what we saw there was sort of a general pullback in a number of the verticals. And we're going to watch that carefully, as Charles said. We don't know whether that's just a result of CMOs taking a breather in the first quarter, given the turmoil or whether that's more structural. In any event, if it is structural, we will make sure that earnings will remain on track, which means we'd have to focus on the expense side. 
But we don't know right now, and we're not going to need your take at this point. 
On the other side of it, the digital and technology platform stuff, up 8%. That's 3 quarters of Epsilon Conversant. And we continue to see very, very strong take up in terms of the data-driven targeted display offerings from Conversant. The number of wins that we're seeing right now are already half of what they were for the entire year last year. And then from an expense perspective and flexibly perspective, our India office is up and running. And we are hopefully continuing to staff that up as the year progresses, and that will finally begin to move the needle on the expense side towards the latter part of the year. 
LoyaltyOne, I think Bryan covered that. Obviously, BrandLoyalty is a very choppy business. It had a -- frankly a little bit better Q1 from the EBITDA perspective than we had initially talked about. But recall last year, Q1 was when revenue was up 100%. So it was then down in Q2. This year, it will be more of the reverse where you'll have a very strong Q2 for BrandLoyalty, and it's all driven by when the grosses have decided to put the programs on the calendar.
Bryan also talked about the BrandLoyalty expansion into North America. Canada is doing quite well and moving nicely towards our goal there. And the U.S. actually we're beginning to make some nice inroads there as well. So good news on that front. 
Again, the concern on the AIR MILES side in Canada was the issuance would fall off as consumer spend was weak. What we found was the reverse, which was issuance is very strong and specifically, issuance in the financial services space, which had been lagging before actually came back quite strongly. So it looks like Canada is still alive and kicking, and doing quite well.
Revenue and EBITDA, plus 4, plus 11, frankly on a constant currency basis was the best we've seen in years. And so it looks like the business up there is back in growth mode. 
Overall, for those of you who have covered ADS for a number of years, it's kind of a typical ADS quarter. You've got a bunch of things that went a little bit better than expected. You had some things that went worse than expected. And the end result is they kind of even out, and we meet or we beat our guidance. And that's pretty much been our track record for the last 15 years. We expect that to be the case going forward as well.
If you look at it in the Cards group, the yields were a little bit worse than we had anticipated, but losses were a little bit better. And then at Epsilon, the digital and tech platforms remained on track. We talked about agency and media was weak. That was offset by the fact in LoyaltyOne that AIR MILES was better, our BrandLoyalty was tracking. So again, looking at us, you can pick and choose whatever data points you want. But at the end of the day, the pluses and minuses, hopefully, even out to get to a double-digit growth rate for the year. And as we turn to our full year guidance, that's exactly what we're saying. It's very straightforward. Now with Q1 behind us, we have even a higher level of confidence on how the rest of the year is going to play out. And we feel very comfortable reiterating our full year guidance of revenue of $7.1 billion, up 10% and earnings of $16.75, up 11%. And the nice thing about it is the slowest quarter is behind us. We're going to ramp up to high single digits in the second quarter, and then we'll do double-digit top and bottom Q3, double-digit top and bottom in Q4, and that will give us a nice jump off into 2017. Visibility is quite strong. 
Q2 guidance revs around $1.6 billion, up 8%. And earnings, also up about 8%. I think those are good numbers to start the acceleration.
From a Card Services perspective, you'll see the principal loss rate forecast that we gave a while ago. And lo and behold, it seems to be playing out at that level, if not just a smidge better, which is good. We expect for the year, Card Services to once again deliver double-digit growth in revenue and adjusted EBITDA net of funding. 
Yield compression, which I'm sure we'll get some questions on, will lessen each quarter as the year progresses, so that we wind up at the end of the year with a very modest compression, which is how we want to take it into '17. And then I always said the pipeline is very robust, and that we'll get into a little bit about our decisions around who to renew, when to renew, at what levels will we renew clients, given that there's a certain amount of capital we want to put into the business, but we want to maintain sort of a 20-plus growth rate in the file, and that means maybe our capital is better spent on other areas and we don't renew certain folks. 
So that's where we are on Epsilon. We talked about digital and tech platforms are 3 cores of the business. We expect that to continue clipping along in the high single digits. The signings for the Conversant CRM vintage, if you recall last year, was about 30 wins in a very strong vintage signing of 80-ish plus. Once they fully spooled up, we expected to lease that this year, if not a little bit better, which will be great. And then now the agency stuff, look we're going to watch it and we're going to see the people-intensive business. It's in about a quarter of Epsilon Conversant. From what we're seeing, it looks soft, but it looks already like it's lessening in terms of the softness as we progress into Q2 and the rest of the year.
Okay. Last slide, full year. LoyaltyOne, BrandLoyalty, Q2 is the big one for them. So expect very, very strong double-digit rev in EBITDA. And then in AIR MILES, we remain comfortable that issuance, which is the key metric there, that's how we get paid, is going to be up about 4% for the year, which will drive on a constant currency basis low single-digit revs, and EBITDA for the year, which again would fly in the face of sort of the weakening consumer in Canada.
Overall, as I mentioned, several moving pieces, but full year is shaping up nicely. We are seeing zero stress on the consumer side. We are not seeing weakness in Canada. So those 2 data points are consistent with last quarter and the quarter before that. I just would talk a little bit about the model itself for Alliance. From 2007 through 2015, we produced annual growth rates of 15% and 18% for revenue and earnings per share, respectively, every single year. And for '16 and '17, as losses normalize and with the huge growth in the file, we're setting aside reserves for future losses, which are essentially doing is, you're knocking that growth rate down a bit. But you're still looking at low end double-digit growth rates in top and bottom. So this year, we're looking at 10% and 11%, and that includes some drag from FX. And then in '18, if, in fact we're right and these rates have stabilized, then there's no reason to doubt that it would snap right back to the prior model, you need to have a reacceleration in growth rate.
So if you look at long term for the company, you're looking somewhere mid-teens to high teens revs and core EPS. Then when you're in a period of normalization and building reserves, you're probably looking at low end, top and bottom double digits. And then you snap back to sort of mid-teens when that normalizes. So overall, not too shabby as a model. You'll also find with us that we tend to have different levers in different businesses cycle up and down at different times. But overall, the model holds together quite nicely. 
For guidance on the last slide, we're keeping at the same, and we're not going to spend a lot of time going through the nits and nats of how we get there. But it looks pretty solid at plus 10%, plus 11%. And that puts our organic growth rate actually quite a bit above our 3x GDP target. We look -- the cash flow, looks very nice. Very strong this year at about $1.4 billion. And look, when it comes to FX and all that other stuff, we'll adjust it when it becomes meaningful as the year plays out. But again, we're not going to be tweaking everything, every quarter. We're going to try to get this thing going on a consolidated basis.
So that's all I have. Why don't we open it up for Q&A? Q&A. Operator?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question comes from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question comes from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question is on the agency side of Epsilon. I guess, Charles, you mentioned that you're not sure if it's structural or not in terms of the weakness there. And maybe, Ed -- Ed or Charles, you can talk about a little bit more. I mean, is tha
componenttext: I guess my first question is on the agency side of Epsilon. I guess, Charles, you mentioned that you're not sure if it's structural or not in terms of the weakness there. And maybe, Ed -- Ed or Charles, you can talk about a little bit more. I mean, is that weakness specific to Epsilon? Or are others seeing similar weakness, obviously adjusting for maybe 1 or 2 large clients that have kind of unique issues?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. Don't know enough yet at this point. We do know I mean, we're not going to say what happened in our business, which was across a number of our verticals, CPG and telco...
componenttext: That's a good question. Don't know enough yet at this point. We do know I mean, we're not going to say what happened in our business, which was across a number of our verticals, CPG and telco...

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Retail.
componenttext: Retail.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And retail. It was interesting, we also have pullback in Q1. It looks like it's beginning to trickle back in as we start moving into Q2, but it's still a little bit soft, so we don't want to call it yet. But it seemed like a lot of people just stepped on
componenttext: And retail. It was interesting, we also have pullback in Q1. It looks like it's beginning to trickle back in as we start moving into Q2, but it's still a little bit soft, so we don't want to call it yet. But it seemed like a lot of people just stepped on the brakes in Q1. So I just don't know what the others are seeing out there right now, Sanjay. But from us, it looks like Q1, people just pulled back. And then as we're looking at Q2, it looks like it's beginning to loosen up a little bit. And so if it continues to loosen up, we're not going to need to take any action. If it continues to stay soft like this, we're going to have to take some internal actions.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I assume you're assuming continued softness for the rest of the year in your guidance?
componenttext: And I assume you're assuming continued softness for the rest of the year in your guidance?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're assuming for the 3 quarters of Epsilon Conversant that's the tech and digital, and everything else. We assume they're going to continue to be quite strong, at about plus 8. And then on the agency side, to your point, we're assuming in our guidance t
componenttext: We're assuming for the 3 quarters of Epsilon Conversant that's the tech and digital, and everything else. We assume they're going to continue to be quite strong, at about plus 8. And then on the agency side, to your point, we're assuming in our guidance that it will be soft, but not nearly as soft as Q1.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just second question, my final question, just on those 2 portfolios that you've chosen or they're not renewing in card. Could you just talk about how that unfolded, kind of why? And how tenured were those relationships?
componenttext: Got it. And then just second question, my final question, just on those 2 portfolios that you've chosen or they're not renewing in card. Could you just talk about how that unfolded, kind of why? And how tenured were those relationships?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this gets -- it's a good question. And we're kind of at the point now where we got the business growing. The files grown 25% a year, which is pretty much -- we don't want to drift much higher than that. But we're also finding that the pipeline, the n
componenttext: Yes, this gets -- it's a good question. And we're kind of at the point now where we got the business growing. The files grown 25% a year, which is pretty much -- we don't want to drift much higher than that. But we're also finding that the pipeline, the number of opportunities that are out there as people shift their dollars to the data-driven targeted spend. Frankly, there's a whole bunch of business out there. And there are times in the past where we've had some clients who've decided not to pour all their energy and efforts into driving tender share growth and card growth. It usually comes with a change in management. Other times, it's a change in strategy. And normally, we've just sort of said that's fine. We'll go with the flow. Right now, we're dealing with how do we allocate our capital? If we want to continue to grow the business, the file, 20-plus percent for the year, how do we maintain the type of returns that we expect. And frankly, there are a couple of programs there that based upon, how do we say it? The comments being made about the dollars that folks are willing to put into it, and the direction of those businesses, it didn't look like the best use of our capital. And so we've reallocated that capital to a couple of wins that we think are, I think, more down the stairway for us. So it's a nice -- I'm trying to be a polite way of saying there's going to be sometimes where the capital is better used elsewhere, and this is one of those times. We've just never been capital constrained, but we're at the point now where the growth rate in the file is pretty much at our max level.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how does it affect the growth assumption for that business?
componenttext: And how does it affect the growth assumption for that business?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It doesn't affect. No, there's no affect at all. It's already been spoken for. And I know we had some -- already some questions about whether it was, which client it was. And obviously we haven't negotiated anything in terms of where we're going to put th
componenttext: It doesn't affect. No, there's no affect at all. It's already been spoken for. And I know we had some -- already some questions about whether it was, which client it was. And obviously we haven't negotiated anything in terms of where we're going to put the file. But it's just -- FYI, it's not any client on the left coast, so that's all I can say on that one.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Darrin Peller with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Darrin Peller with Barclays.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just quickly follow-up on the Epsilon side. I mean, if you can give us a little more granularity first into the strength of the tech and data side there? I know Conversant in the pipeline looks strong still. But I mean, I guess I just want to make
componenttext: Let me just quickly follow-up on the Epsilon side. I mean, if you can give us a little more granularity first into the strength of the tech and data side there? I know Conversant in the pipeline looks strong still. But I mean, I guess I just want to make sure that's sustainable in terms of -- you're not seeing the same lines on a agency side pullback any at all on the tech side. Obviously, the growth doesn't show that yet. And then if you can you give us a little more color on the levers that you have capable of pulling from a cost standpoint at Epsilon if it has to start next quarter, I guess how much room do we have? It feels like an area that you're trying to cut costs in the past and outsource I think to India, et cetera? So I look to see more color on how much room there is.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, right now, what we're seeing is continuation of a strong demand for the Digital Products at Conversant, specifically sort of the SKU level, data-driven targeted display offering. Very strong. In general, the more core Epsilon, Big Loyalty and
componenttext: Yes. I mean, right now, what we're seeing is continuation of a strong demand for the Digital Products at Conversant, specifically sort of the SKU level, data-driven targeted display offering. Very strong. In general, the more core Epsilon, Big Loyalty and customer data base builds are strong and data offerings are strong. So a lot of -- all that heavy tech stuff demand continues to be strong. We expect that to continue for the rest of the year. On the agency side, look, we need to be very careful, we don't knee-jerk this thing. If it's an air pocket, then great, and we're back in business. If it looks like it's softer than we expect, then it's a very project intensive, people-intensive business. You would have to move quickly to make sure that revenues and expenses sync up. But what we're seeing right now is the softness in Q1 is already lessening a bit as we move into Q2. So we're going to hold off knee-jerking this thing. And if, in fact, Q2 comes in very soft on the agency side, we'll still make our numbs for the company from a guidance perspective, for sure. But we'll have to take some expenses out to make sure we take our numbers for the year.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I just missed it, but in terms of 5%, what was your overall Epsilon outlook for the year now in terms of organic growth for the whole segment?
componenttext: Maybe I just missed it, but in terms of 5%, what was your overall Epsilon outlook for the year now in terms of organic growth for the whole segment?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we talked about for Epsilon is mid-single digit, less from top and bottom. I think we'll stay there.
componenttext: What we talked about for Epsilon is mid-single digit, less from top and bottom. I think we'll stay there.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Staying there? Okay, all right. Let me just shift in and then I'll turn it back to the queue. But on the Private Label, the Card Services side, I guess first on growth, do you agree I mean, co-branding I know is tougher now from a competitive standpoint.
componenttext: Staying there? Okay, all right. Let me just shift in and then I'll turn it back to the queue. But on the Private Label, the Card Services side, I guess first on growth, do you agree I mean, co-branding I know is tougher now from a competitive standpoint. So just revisiting the addressable market in terms of opportunities, obviously given your -- I think this is the first time I remember hearing you guys adapting a couple of portfolios based on better opportunities, probably more profitability elsewhere. But either way, I mean, I guess just revisiting the addressable market would be helpful given it seems like it's more Private Label focused than co-branding now. And then on that note, the yield compression is a combination of things, like you guys mentioned automated payments and new vintages but also co-branding. With all of those things anniversary-ing and co-branding potentially moving lower now as a potential mix, should the yield potentially rise in '17 or will it be stable?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the yield will be relatively stable in '17, exactly to your point, as we're burning through these compression issues and to anniversary. And to your point exactly, a little less emphasis on the co-brand side. You won't have that sort of large comp
componenttext: I think the yield will be relatively stable in '17, exactly to your point, as we're burning through these compression issues and to anniversary. And to your point exactly, a little less emphasis on the co-brand side. You won't have that sort of large compression that you've seen in the last couple of years, 100 basis points or so on the yield side. It'll be significantly less than that. And that has to do again, with -- we're looking to optimize the portfolio, which means that in this part of the cycle, you've got an awful lot of mouths to feed when it comes to co-brand, so that isn't quite as exciting to us at this point in the cycle. We've seen this play out before. So we're looking to optimize the file, continue the growth at 20-plus percent, and keep the compression much more modest on a go-forward basis. And based on the pipeline and what we're signing, and what you'll see release later this year, we feel pretty good with it.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin McVeigh with Macquarie.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Right. So 5 a loss rate...

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Including the -- we came in a little bit better in Q1. I think you'll see we could come in a little bit better in Q2 and Q3. It could be up a little bit in Q4 compared to original guidance, but I would say we're right on track to hit the 5% for the year.
componenttext: Including the -- we came in a little bit better in Q1. I think you'll see we could come in a little bit better in Q2 and Q3. It could be up a little bit in Q4 compared to original guidance, but I would say we're right on track to hit the 5% for the year. In terms of mid-teens, we're always doing better by 10 bps in the first quarter, some of its timing. But I'd say for the year, we're tracking right to the 5 -- loss rate that we gave as guidance.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then as we think about the mix of Private Label versus co-brand going forward, are we still kind of, in a range you talked about historically, or more of a shift on the Private Label side?
componenttext: Got it. And then as we think about the mix of Private Label versus co-brand going forward, are we still kind of, in a range you talked about historically, or more of a shift on the Private Label side?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say we're still around 80-20, 80% Private Label, 20% co-brand. To Ed's point before, we're doing less co-brand as where the most of the competition is. We're focused more on Private Label. You know us, Private Label's our secret sauce. That's where we
componenttext: I'd say we're still around 80-20, 80% Private Label, 20% co-brand. To Ed's point before, we're doing less co-brand as where the most of the competition is. We're focused more on Private Label. You know us, Private Label's our secret sauce. That's where we have all the expertise. And so you'll see more growth coming there which long term should benefit yields, going back to Darin's question before.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bob Napoli with William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bob Napoli with William Blair.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed just -- and Charles, are the additional buybacks in your guidance, you bought back about 5 -- buy $400 million, you said you have $500 million, and I think you expect to buy back closer to $800 million to $1 billion?
componenttext: Ed just -- and Charles, are the additional buybacks in your guidance, you bought back about 5 -- buy $400 million, you said you have $500 million, and I think you expect to buy back closer to $800 million to $1 billion?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the second piece of our authorization is not considered Bob, so the initial $500 million was considered the second $500 million, it's not considered in guidance.
componenttext: So the second piece of our authorization is not considered Bob, so the initial $500 million was considered the second $500 million, it's not considered in guidance.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then on the tender share improvement, the 80% for mature accounts, it's very helpful. But is that piece being driven by increasing credit lines for those individuals that are using the line? And obviously since they're mature accounts, I'm sure they
componenttext: Okay. Then on the tender share improvement, the 80% for mature accounts, it's very helpful. But is that piece being driven by increasing credit lines for those individuals that are using the line? And obviously since they're mature accounts, I'm sure they're performing well, credit wise?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it's -- we're not tossing up lines. We've never had really an issue with open to buy. I think Charles, you may know better than I. We have the $500 balance, we may have an $800 line. So there's plenty of room on the open to buy, and we rescor
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's -- we're not tossing up lines. We've never had really an issue with open to buy. I think Charles, you may know better than I. We have the $500 balance, we may have an $800 line. So there's plenty of room on the open to buy, and we rescore all 40 million accounts every quarter. So it's not a credit line issue. It's more of, if I have an $800 line and a $500 balance and I'm growing it normally 5% a year, how do I get it to 7% or 8%? And that's basically the whole tender share again, which is how do I get her to make one more visit if they're not visiting the store itself. A lot of our tender share gains, I'd say the bulk of it is coming through online sales, where we reach out to her and make some type of compelling offer to her and she'll go online to buy it. A lot of this is to use the lingo, she's snacking online, meaning that we're seeing a lot of incremental purchases that are relatively small in size, but they're happening very frequently.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then last question, on the agency business, on the Epsilon business, is that -- I mean, have you lost -- is this just pulled back by client? Have you lost some clients? Are you losing share of a client to another competitor or piece? So what's
componenttext: Great. And then last question, on the agency business, on the Epsilon business, is that -- I mean, have you lost -- is this just pulled back by client? Have you lost some clients? Are you losing share of a client to another competitor or piece? So what's going on there? I don't think the industry has pulled back as much as we saw in your business in the first quarter. And who are you primarily competing with today in these sectors?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question. We don't -- one quarter doesn't a trend make. So it's still up in the air in terms of what exactly. All we did see was we saw project business basically dry out in the first quarter. But we accounted on and as a result, the business
componenttext: It's a good question. We don't -- one quarter doesn't a trend make. So it's still up in the air in terms of what exactly. All we did see was we saw project business basically dry out in the first quarter. But we accounted on and as a result, the business we needed to close to make agency hit Q1 didn't happen. Now are those projects beginning to drift back in? It looks like they're slowly drifting back in. So that's all we know at this point.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Who are you seeing as your, I mean, by sector or agency versus tech, would you point out as your 2 or 3 largest and toughest competitors?
componenttext: Who are you seeing as your, I mean, by sector or agency versus tech, would you point out as your 2 or 3 largest and toughest competitors?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's all over the board in terms of when its pure agency, you can have the big Madison Avenue players involved there. You can have some of the other digital smaller agencies involved there. But for the most part what we do is we like to link the a
componenttext: I think it's all over the board in terms of when its pure agency, you can have the big Madison Avenue players involved there. You can have some of the other digital smaller agencies involved there. But for the most part what we do is we like to link the agency as sort of the tip of the arrow to get in the door with the CMO to flow through to the big, heavy duty high visibility tech platforms that we built for them. The project base stuff on the agency side, as you can tell is the stuff that can jerk around quite a bit on a quarterly basis. So, that's sort of -- we're seeing the big tech platforms continue to be built. And it's just these projects on the agency side that we just saw softness in Q1. So we just don't want to get out in front of this thing and start saying, oh my gosh, we've got long-term weakness in the agency when it could very well just be a 1 quarter phenomenon.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bob, the only thing I would add is it's not a case where we're losing clients. It's not the number of clients going weigh just less spend. So in the first quarter, we really saw less spend, going back to Ed's point on a project basis, CMOs cut their bu
componenttext: So Bob, the only thing I would add is it's not a case where we're losing clients. It's not the number of clients going weigh just less spend. So in the first quarter, we really saw less spend, going back to Ed's point on a project basis, CMOs cut their budgets with us for whatever reason.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey, and he's with SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey, and he's with SunTrust.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, I guess I want to ask a big picture strategic question with regard to Epsilon. Is there -- as you think about agency, irrespective sort of the quarterly volatility in that business, is there still the same sort of competitive strategic rationale for h
componenttext: Ed, I guess I want to ask a big picture strategic question with regard to Epsilon. Is there -- as you think about agency, irrespective sort of the quarterly volatility in that business, is there still the same sort of competitive strategic rationale for having the agency as part of Epsilon as you might have thought there was 5 years ago? Has your thinking changed on that at all?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's absolutely critical that we have that skill set, because that's the skill set that can get in the door, have the conversation with the CMO. And that will then lead to the pull through to the big client database where the big loyalty platf
componenttext: No, I think it's absolutely critical that we have that skill set, because that's the skill set that can get in the door, have the conversation with the CMO. And that will then lead to the pull through to the big client database where the big loyalty platform builds, the big CRM business like Conversant. So no, I think the skill set there is critical in order to pull through for the other parts of Epsilon. It's almost like if even though it's a bit soft this quarter, my view is if you take it away, what you're going to wind out with is you're going to cut the head off the rest of the big tech pull throughs at the rest of Epsilon and the whole thing will eventually slow down.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is there -- with regard to, again agency, is there a customer concentration issue you think within that business? Is that part of the reason we see the volatility? Is there anything you can do about it if there is?
componenttext: Okay. And is there -- with regard to, again agency, is there a customer concentration issue you think within that business? Is that part of the reason we see the volatility? Is there anything you can do about it if there is?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is part of it, Andrew. If you look our biggest clients in Epsilon are all on the agency side of the business. So when they pullback on an any project or maybe not supporting us this particular offering, they can move the needle quickly. And being proje
componenttext: It is part of it, Andrew. If you look our biggest clients in Epsilon are all on the agency side of the business. So when they pullback on an any project or maybe not supporting us this particular offering, they can move the needle quickly. And being project based, they can do volatility in through the quarter. Quite a bit for the year, you can pretty well estimate what they're going to do. But they can basically open up a bit faster or close it quite quickly based upon what they're willing to do with the marketing spend. And so what we saw in Q1 was they basically closed the spigot. We think that they will open it up as the year progresses, so we're not sounding alarm bells. But it is big companies, big budgets and they can flex it quite quickly.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then quickly, with regard to your outlook for what maybe a loss rate plateau in '18 and beyond, can you dig a little bit into the rationale and thought process that gives you confidence that we might see something that's pretty unprecedented his
componenttext: Okay. And then quickly, with regard to your outlook for what maybe a loss rate plateau in '18 and beyond, can you dig a little bit into the rationale and thought process that gives you confidence that we might see something that's pretty unprecedented historically in terms of stable charge-offs?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you look at it, it's a great question. The fact that as we talked about the bulk of our growth, the 10% in the core growth that we're seeing is really coming from accounts that are very mature, have been well seasoned, well passed the peak
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at it, it's a great question. The fact that as we talked about the bulk of our growth, the 10% in the core growth that we're seeing is really coming from accounts that are very mature, have been well seasoned, well passed the peak charge-off cycle. We are normalizing the loss rate. I think may be 2 more staffs might be helpful, which is look, we thought before the Great Recession, our normalized loss rate was 6.5%. We're seeing its 5.5% now. Why is that? Why are we comfortable that that's our long-term run rate, and that's what we're normalizing towards. Probably a couple of interesting stats there. One is with the new mix of co-brand, which carries a higher scoring customer as well as some of the higher-end type retailers that have joined us, we're attracting cardholders that tend to skew a little bit higher on the credit spectrum. So for example, if you were to compare all of our active accounts today versus 2007, the scores today on average are higher than they were in 2007, even with some of -- a lot of the accounts we've added recently. So from an active account basis, the average score is higher. Also if you looked at it from a balance perspective, the average score per balance today is higher than it was in 2007. And so you put those 2 together and that's how you get to -- we're not going to normalize out of 6.5%, we're going to normalize out of 5.5%. But look, it's not like we're trying to keep it lower. The fact is you give up some yield by not being at a higher loss rate. So I'm not sure it's a strategy of ours to keep it at 5.5%. It's just the way the file is playing out right now.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Ashish Sabadra with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Ashish Sabadra with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on the agency weakness here. So the agency has both Conversant as well as core Epsilon. I'm just wondering if the 23% decline that you see that was consistent across both those segments? And then Charles, you mentioned that there is
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on the agency weakness here. So the agency has both Conversant as well as core Epsilon. I'm just wondering if the 23% decline that you see that was consistent across both those segments? And then Charles, you mentioned that there is inter-quarter volatility there depending on the projects. Is there something you can do strategically going forward to lower that volatility? Or is it just that as tech continues to grow faster, it will be a bigger portion of the revenues? I was just wondering, how should we think about the volatility coming down in the agency because it has been volatile over the last several quarters now?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're right, Ashish. We're going to have to grow the technology piece of the business quicker. That's just, frankly where it's going to be. Agency in a good year is going to grow 3%, technology in a good year is going to grow 10 plus. So from a mix stand
componenttext: You're right, Ashish. We're going to have to grow the technology piece of the business quicker. That's just, frankly where it's going to be. Agency in a good year is going to grow 3%, technology in a good year is going to grow 10 plus. So from a mix standpoint, you'll basically take some of the volatility away from it. If you look at the breakdown, it was weakness in both categories. We saw weakness in traditional agency for Epsilon, where we saw weakness across many verticals. I couldn't pinpoint any one client because it was broad-based. On the Conversant side, on the traditional display, we've definitely seen pure people trying to use our private exchange. You've got the big agencies trying to push the programmatic client through their own trading platforms. So regardless of the quality, the impressions we can provide, they're trying to stuff it through their own system, and we just saw a general pullback there. So that was a little bit unexpected. So I'd say it was both sides of it. We do think we'll get some stability as the year goes on, but there's really, going back to Ed's point, nothing in particular, we can point to aside from it. Just seemed like there was soft spend in Q1.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just quickly on the margins for the Epsilon business. You highlighted a couple of reasons for the margins being lower, but how should we think about margins going forward? Technically, if agency attempts to be a lower margin, tech was a higher margi
componenttext: Okay. Just quickly on the margins for the Epsilon business. You highlighted a couple of reasons for the margins being lower, but how should we think about margins going forward? Technically, if agency attempts to be a lower margin, tech was a higher margin business and as tech is growing faster, you would expect the margins to go up going forward. So just wanted to better understand how should we think about the dynamics for Epsilon margins over the next several quarters, but also the longer term?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the way you look at it is basically, you're right. Agency will grow slower. It's the lower EBITDA margin, your technology will grow quicker. It's the highest EBITDA margin. So it's from a pure mix standpoint. You should get some EBITDA margin expansion
componenttext: So the way you look at it is basically, you're right. Agency will grow slower. It's the lower EBITDA margin, your technology will grow quicker. It's the highest EBITDA margin. So it's from a pure mix standpoint. You should get some EBITDA margin expansion in this year and in the future. Clearly, we'll have to look at the agency and play through if it's the short-term hiccup or air pocket as I said before, or it is the case where we have to structurally cut back on cost to get our margins back where they need to be. That's a little bit of the unknown at this point. But long term, I would expect the margins to expand slightly based on mix.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And one final question on the gross yield compression. So the late fees have been weighing on -- the lower late fees have been weighing on which is actually better because it helps you, or it's reflective of the better consumer
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And one final question on the gross yield compression. So the late fees have been weighing on -- the lower late fees have been weighing on which is actually better because it helps you, or it's reflective of the better consumer environment. But just how should we think about that compression, like how much visibility or how much confidence do you have that comes off the second half and going into '17?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have very good visibility into this as we go into the second half. A large chunk of it, probably half of it, relates to what I call consumer-friendly programs, which I probably should find. It basically is we look at all of our practices, and basi
componenttext: Yes. We have very good visibility into this as we go into the second half. A large chunk of it, probably half of it, relates to what I call consumer-friendly programs, which I probably should find. It basically is we look at all of our practices, and basically said how do we continue to be the premium provider in the marketplace, the most customer-friendly provider in the marketplace as we continue to ramp up? And so there's a bunch of things that we put in place as we went into back half of last year. So for example, it doesn't seem like a lot, but it does move the needle in terms of if someone gets paid on the 15th of each month, but their bill is due on the 13th. Well, that doesn't work out all that well sometimes. So what we've done is we've given everyone the right to move their due date to later on in the month, if they wanted to. And that, again, it doesn't seem like much, but it actually does affect the late fees. But at the same time, it also helps our OpEx as you can see with the leverage because we have much lower talk time of people calling off, saying hey, I need a couple more days. So you have that. You have people who are calling in, where there used to be a fee if you're paying by the phone. We decided that wasn't best practices. We took that out as well. And so we just took a number of things out of the system that frankly caused more grief than they added. We got a lot of it back in lower OpEx in terms of talk time and everything else, and we have a much happier client and customer base. And so I think that's sort of what it is. None of it was dictated by any regulatory authority. It was something we proactively went out and just did. And we think, taking the hit now for it, and seeing it anniversary in the back half is probably the best thing to do. And hopefully, that will pay dividends down the line.

componenttext: I'll apologize in advance, Ed, because it's sort of a repeat of some that have been asked, but I just want a clarification. Obviously, it's all based on CMO budgets. But is the vast majority of the business, things that you would deem to be, quarter-by-quarter project base where there isn't necessarily great visibility?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Definitely on the Epsilon side of it, that's the case, whereas you got 1- or 2-year contracts but it's project to project. On the Conversant side, it's going to be more volume driven because it's basically side display. So basically, you've got a lot of unpredictably when you get to agency. You can have a longer-term contract but if it's flexed based on volume, predicting what it's going to be on a quarter-to-quarter basis it's just a difficult thing to do, David.

But from the standpoint of the percentage of fixed cost, how should we think about it?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say your premise is right, David. It is a higher fixed cost of business. It's more of a people-driven business, so variability is pretty low. Part of the reason why you saw that our EBITDA was down quite a bit in the quarter was because the revenue wa
componenttext: I'd say your premise is right, David. It is a higher fixed cost of business. It's more of a people-driven business, so variability is pretty low. Part of the reason why you saw that our EBITDA was down quite a bit in the quarter was because the revenue was down on agency and it doesn't flex very much. So you're right. I don't have any exact percentage, but you can assume, it is our highest fixed cost business would be within agency. So if we see it's a structural issue in the market then we'll have to go through and address the fixed cost, and we can do so pretty quickly if we need to.

We have looked for the year to be the same way. So it's very difficult for me to quantify that for you by quarter, David.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
