headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Alliance Data Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In order to view the company's presentation on their website, please remember to turn off all the pop-up blocker on your computer. It is n
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Alliance Data Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In order to view the company's presentation on their website, please remember to turn off all the pop-up blocker on your computer. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Steve Calk of FTI Consulting. Sir, the floor is yours. 
[Audio Gap]
Double-digit revenue and adjusted EBITDA for both LoyaltyOne and Card Services, a return to positive revenue growth at Epsilon and stable FX rates. Another positive during the quarter was the opportunity to acquire earlier than scheduled the remaining 20% ownership in BrandLoyalty. It made sense to us as the company's performance has exceeded all of our expectations and the opportunity in North America looks very compelling. 
Accordingly, we acquired remaining interest effective April 1, 2016, for approximately $259 million in consideration, which was funded by upside in BrandLoyalty's credit facility. 
Now the accounting is little unique because the remaining ownership was purchased prior to the 10% tranches scheduled for January 17 and January 18, the consideration paid exceeded the current value of the redeemable now controlling interest our balance sheet, which would've increased over the next 1.5 years to roughly equal the purchase price paid. The difference of $68 million is immediate charge to retain earnings on the balance sheet but nonetheless, it's considered in the calculation of EPS, which was reduced by $1.14. Excluding this charge, EPS increased 13% for the second quarter. 
While this acquisition means to ADS? From the revenue standpoint, nothing as we already consolidate 100% of BrandLoyalty's revenue. From a profitable standpoint, it will add a few cents to our EPS and our core EPS for 2016. 
Turning to the repurchase program. We've acquired approximately 2.6 million shares under our repurchase program year-to-date. We have approximately 460 million of our board authorization left, which we expect to use somewhat ratably over the remainder of 2016. 
Let's go to Page 3 and talk about LoyaltyOne. LoyaltyOne had a very strong second quarter as revenue increased 17% to $352 million and adjusted EBITDA increased 20% to $79 million. Negative FX translation rates knocked up about 2 points upgrowth off to the second quarter, but on a positive the note, we do not expect any FX drag in the second half of 2016 if current spot rates hold. 
AIR MILES' revenue increased 6% on a constant currency basis, driven by an 8% increase in miles redeemed. 
AIR MILES issued declined 3% versus the same quarter last year, which was expected. As you may recall, we converted Sobeys legacy reward program into the AIR MILES reward program in the second quarter of 2015. That makes for a difficult year-over-year comparable. 
In addition, we had less promotional activity in the grocery vertical this year. AIR MILES redeemed increased 8% compared to the second quarter 2015, primarily driven by AM Cash or instant reward option. 
In particular, we are seeing growth in in-store redemptions, which are popular at our AIR MILES grocery partners. 
Moving to BrandLoyalty. Revenue increased 44% on a constant currency basis, driven by an increase in the number of short term loyalty programs executed during the quarter. 
Continued expansion into new markets such as South Africa and New Zealand contributed to growth. The pilot recently executed with the top 3 grocery in the U.S. finished with a very strong results as pilot stores showed revenue growth approximately 1.5% higher than non-pilot stores. 
This was accomplished largely through an increased basket sizes. Plans are currently underway with this grocery to extend the program the full store network at later day. Additional pilot programs in the U.S. and Canada are also planned for the back half of this year. Overall, a terrific quarter. 
Now let's flip over to the next slide and talk about Epsilon. Epsilon's revenue increased 5% to $519 million for the second quarter, a solid turn from the revenue decline of 2% in the first quarter of 2016. 
Adjusted EBITDA decreased 9% to $103 million, primarily due to the duplicate cost in R&D operation and severance costs. We expect these costs to abate during the third quarter allowing the full flow through of revenue to EBITDA. 
Our digital and technology platforms businesses is hot, posting robust 14% growth versus the prior year. This performance was supported by solid contributions from all offerings in this category with our automotive platform and Conversant CRM service leading the way. 
In addition, solid traction in the affiliate business and strong new business within our Harmony platform added momentum. 
In particular,, Conversant CRM business with industry-leading cross-device recognition and reach had a terrific quarter with revenue of 66% and a building backlog that should exceed the book of business we won in 2015 with over 20 new clients signed and launched in the first half, including Zales, Beach Body, Justice and White House black market. 
Our agency media & services business continues to struggle as revenue declined 15% versus the prior year. This offering has been weak for several quarters due to a combination of decreased spending by large customer in our traditional agency and lower volume of digital media buys from large third party agencies. 
In response, 3 initiatives were started during the second quarter. The first would suggest the cost structure commensurate with low revenue expectations that is largely complete. The second, which is a longer-term initiative is to redirect the digital agency toward mid-sized agencies and maybe direct to clients.  Third, we've begun pivoting this offering to core data-driven marketing and insights, thus creating a CRM-like solution for clients who aren't ready yet for full CRM. Earlier results are encouraging as we've begun to gain traction in new verticals such as media and entertainment. 
Overall, we see 2 key market trends align well with Epsilon's core strategy: Demands from CMOs for measurable results and the ongoing shift from traditional marketing channels to digital and data-driven channels. With a highly differentiated digital and offline data asset, a rich portfolio of services and its deep marketing advertising technology stack, the business is poised to resume healthy steady growth. 
Topic declines are growing at a high single digit rate and the business has robust topline.  Paired with prudent cost management initiatives currently underway, we expect to see the return to profitable growth in the back half of 2016 and exit the year with a healthier cost structure going into 2017. 
I will now turn it over to Melisa to talk about Card Services.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charles. Good morning, everyone. Turning now to Page 5. I am so pleased to highlight that the Card Services business had another quarter of strong performance, delivering the 18 consecutive quarter of double-digit revenue growth. Revenues are
componenttext:
Thank you, Charles. Good morning, everyone. Turning now to Page 5. I am so pleased to highlight that the Card Services business had another quarter of strong performance, delivering the 18 consecutive quarter of double-digit revenue growth. 
Revenues are up 25% over last year, translating to a 10% increase in adjusted EBITDA net of funding costs. 
Let's turn now to Page 6 and go over some of the key drivers of the strong performance. First, credit sales were up 18%, resulting in year-over-year tender share gains on 180 basis points were measurable. Now each quarter, you hear us comment on tender share, and we do so because it really is a fundamental metric to the success of our programs. And what may be helpful context here is these tender share gains we reference come from our legacy programs, and do not include any gains from our newer card programs. Put differently, the tender share gains we reference are results of increasing the number of trips, spend and card member retention from those card programs with us prior to 2013. 
Importantly, the average tenure of our 12 months active shopper is 5 years, and the sales distribution of our most tenured card members has been remarkably stable for 4 years. 
And I mentioned this because these are highly seasoned relationships and as such, we have great visibility into their past behavior, and that allows us to accurately predict how our card members will behave in the future. These gains are not a result of any widening, loosening or lessening of our credit standards. And is consistent increase in tender share is really a result of that data-driven targeted marketing no more sell more brand promise, and the increases this year are certainly a signal of card members growing engagement with our brand partners. 
Second, as expected, gross yields are normalizing and the year-over-year compression is lessening and with very good visibility into the remainder of the year, we expect to achieve our annual guidance for gross yields of 25.1% as well. 
Third, operating expenses grew 24% this quarter, while improving 40 basis points to 9.5% of our average card receivables. And even with this improvement, we continue to make investments in preparation for the onboarding of several new partners from diverse retail verticals. For example, we deliberately entered the high gross segment of fast fashion with our recently announced Forever 21 partnership. We look forward to announcing additional significant partnerships in the coming quarters. 
And this year as in years past, the new partnerships we will sign represent more than $2 billion in steady-state accounts receivable. Our pipeline remains robust as we continue to identify strong potential partners that are passionate about driving consumer engagement in line with the revolving need and view the card program as the ultimate loyalty tool. 
And fourth, our loss rate for the quarter came in at 5.1% in line with prior guidance, and we remain confident in achieving our guidance of a 5% loss rate for the full year. 
We continue to see success in this proven ability to drive stronger engagement and loyalty through our tailored marketing solutions driven largely by these data analytics, insights and innovative capabilities. 
Now speaking of engagement, let's spend just a moment to cover up on some of the brands we most recently on boarded. We're super enthusiastic about the progress of our newer partners. They're posting very strong results year-over-year, and I wanted to take just a moment to share 2 very specific examples. 
One partner experienced greater than as 70% increase in application volume and a credit sales jump of 37% thus driving tender share gains of more than 800 basis points with just a few months post conversion. And another important partners on tender share gains of 400 basis points and credit sales increases of 45% post-conversion. These gains are really due to our improved tools and stronger multi-channel engagement and are, again, testament to the increase to spend we generate for our brand partners. 
Now we also know that despite these strong program results, concerns still exist in the market around the strength and health of the U.S. consumer. Candidly, we are seeing very few signs of concern. Our view is that consumer confidence is stable, delinquency trends are within expected parameters, card retention is very strong, and we continue to find success in engaging brands and their customers. We are welcoming card members to our programs well the existing card members continue to spend across channel. 
Now if I can comment just a moment about the consumer spend. To be clear, they are spending and they are spending differently. 
For instance, in some categories, we see our digital credit sales, so those sales outside of the brick and mortar environment, growing significantly year-over-year specialty retail currently sees digital credit sales over 40%, which is certainly higher than digital sales for the brand and has been steadily climbing. 
Similarly, 67% of home to core credit sales now come through digital channels, nearly a 10% jump in just 2 years. Multi-channel shoppers, so those actively purchasing both in-store and digitally are our fastest-growing segment, and they are also the most valuable to our partners. These multi-channel shoppers spent twice as much as digital and single-channel shoppers and looking more broadly, nearly 4 out of 10 applications are now completed outside of the store, with mobile applications, in particular, the fastest-growing channel. This continuing shift to mobile is reflective of consumer behavior as it is the channel where she increasingly chooses to engage with her favorite brands. 
As early adopters in the mobile space, we've been innovating on this trend for many years and believe it will continue to accelerate. As such, our investment strategy remains focused on delivering [indiscernible] capabilities that bring the most value to card members and our brand partners, facilitating deeper loyalty and ultimately, increased spend. 
For example, our MyLoyalty app solution continues to help brands cater to, engage with, card members as they apply, shop, earn and redeem all through a seamless, intuitive and highly targeted customer experience. 
A newer capabilities such as the development of a proprietary mobile application experience that significantly reduces its customer time and effort serves the changing consumer who's looking for every into action to be fabulous. 
So in summary, Card Services has delivered another strong quarter, producing results in line with our high expectations. We're confident in our full year guidance around our loss rate, our yields have stabilized ahead of our expectations, and we remain confident in our consumer outlook and the overall quality and performance of our card members. 
Our investments and partnerships aligned to the evolving needs of both our brands customers and the retail landscape overall. That's demonstrating the value we bring to our partners through our broader retail heritage and our experienced lends to the market. 
Thanks so much. And Ed, I'll turn this over to you.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Melisa. Why don't we turn to the second quarter store card, we'll try to wrap this up as neatly as we can. And we're going with the color-coded circles on the left. We're looking for more green than other colors, that would be a good thing.
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Melisa. Why don't we turn to the second quarter store card, we'll try to wrap this up as neatly as we can. And we're going with the color-coded circles on the left. We're looking for more green than other colors, that would be a good thing. And as we are midway through the year, it looks like we're heading in the right direction. 
So to sort of sum it up on a consolidated basis, $1.75 billion in revs, up 17%, $3.68 in EPS, up 11%. 
I think for those of you who have been hearing Charles and I talk about how the year would play out, we talked about a Q1, sort of plus 5 top, plus 5 bottom, and then Q2, move into 8 and 8 and then eventually double-digit in the back half. The fact that we're at 17 in Q2 and 11 on the bottom in Q2 as well essentially means that we pulled -- we're running ahead by a quarter. So essentially, the back half has been accelerated and that essentially what you're seeing in Q2. We were -- we had some signs of things we're accelerating, but of course, we wanted to be able to deliver more careful into what actually played through. So I think the way to look at the quarter is it's not unexpected that we're running at double-digit. What was unexpected is that we're running a double-digit this early in the year. So that certainly takes the risk out of the back half of the year. We're nicely ahead of guidance, and in fact, we feel comfortable raising guidance at this point for the year. As Charles mentioned, the buyback, we're about halfway through and the year is about halfway through,and we'll leave it at that. 
Now let's turn to Card Services. Melisa talked extensively about performance once again. Very strong growth in the overall portfolio, and we do talk on and on about tender share because that is so important to us. That's sort of what makes or breaks our model versus other models out there and essentially, that is the ability of triggering an additional purchase or visit with a purchase by the shopper over and above what she would traditionally do. And that's all done through our data-driven marketing and targeting. 
And as most have talked about, 85% of this tender share gain is from very mature accounts. Folks have been with us for years and years and years. It's not a function of just pumping more plastic out into the marketplace, and that something that's important. 
So the model works. Probably the biggest surprise for the quarter in terms of good news was the gross yield certainly came in well ahead of expectations. 
Specifically, if you recall, Q1 is where we saw the compression in yields of 210 basis points. We suggested that we thought this would roll off as the year progressed, as we anniversary various programs. We actually saw a faster burn in Q2. And as a result, we picked up a very, very nice chunk of revenues from the gross yield compressor being less than expected. 
So put simply, we went from 200 basis points compression in Q1 all the way down to 80 basis points in Q2 and then we'll trickle ahead for the rest of the year a little bit better than that as the final programs burn through. 
So those probably the first good news surprise for the quarter. Losses, they're dead on. There is not a lot to talk about there. We talked about a 5% loss rate for the full year way back at the beginning of the year. We are dead on with that number as we look to the back half, so no surprises there. There's no big cliff heading our way out there, it's pretty straightforward and this is just normal account seasoning. And as Melisa said, there's no distress that we're  seeing in the consumers so a very straightforward on the loss side. 
And then obviously, what Melisa and I spend a lot of time on is what is the future look like? And the future, again, looks very promising. We've just announced thus Boscov’s, Forever 21, Children’s Place, Bed Bath & Beyond, Hot Topic. We probably have another half dozen that are signed, including a couple of biggies that we will be announcing in the back half of the year. So very, very robust signing season for Card Services. 
So I think that's it for cards. We move now on to Epsilon, where we have moved from a green yellow and red to now green and yellow, which I think is a good thing. And I probably would say the second, if you would call it piece of good news our surprise for the quarter, was that we knew Epsilon was turning and again, Epsilon includes both Epsilon core as well as the Conversant folks. And in Q1, obviously, it was a disappointing quarter. Revenues were down 2%. Our goal was to swing that to positive a couple of points by Q2 and then hit mid-single digits as we move into the back half and accelerate from there. Again, the news here was that the revenue acceleration occurred faster than we had anticipated and we actually swung from minus 2 to plus 5 between Q1 and Q2. So 7 points growth -- change in growth is quite a bit. And needless to say, we were pleased to see that. We expect that type of performance to continue, if not tick up as we go into the back half. And as Charles mentioned, the good news now is once we have a top line turned, the cost structure should play out as soon as the quarter we're in now, Q3. So essentially, as we've talked to people, we had a -- we're in the process over the last year of a very significant ramp up as we build up our in depth operation, and we had a lot of the duplicative cost, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera. The bottom line is the flow through will begin in Q3 and that should put us in a very good shape for not only the back half, but more importantly, as we go into next year and the following year. So that would be what we call the Q3 flip for lack of a better term. 
And then I'd like to spend just a couple of seconds on Conversant. So Conversant became part of Alliance at the beginning of last year. And obviously, it was met with a fair amount of skepticism out there. Some of it made a lot of sense, some of it, we disagreed with. But at this point, if you look at the 3 pieces of Conversant, sort of the traditional Conversant before we went into how we reported today sort of mashed up with the core Epsilon, it has 3 pieces. The traditional Conversant had about a quarter of the business in agency and that is probably we're going to run down for the, year probably 15% or something like that. Then you have a quarter of the business that's what we call CJ affiliate, and that's running nicely at mid-single digits up and a very strong cash flow contributor. And then you have the biggest piece, half of Conversant, which is the data-driven CRM piece, and that is running between 40% and 50% for the year. And that is -- that's really the huge piece, and you obviously want your biggest piece to be fur fastest-grower. So if you put it all together, what you essentially have is in Q2, if you look at Conversant from a traditional perspective, you would have seen double-digit top consolidated of all 3 pieces and double-digit bottom. And I raise that because of the fact that, that was our goal. If we went back to the original pieces beyond the acquisition, we knew that the affiliate business is a good business, and we'll chug along. We knew that the agency business would be pressured, and we need to find a way to distinguish that from the other businesses. But primarily, the CRM business, we were hoping for the huge cross sell for the last of Alliance. That has happened, and that as a result, we are seeing sort of 10% top and bottom that the original deal was based upon. 
So as far as we're concerned, we hit our goals from the original deal. You look at BrandLoyalty, obviously, came out of the gate double-digit across-the-board right from the beginning of the acquisition, so the 2 deals we've done on the last 3, 4 years have performed quite nicely. Some started a little bit faster than others. But right now, both seem to be producing. And as we move into the LoyaltyOne segment, and we talk about BrandLoyalty. We mentioned in Q1 that it is a lumpy business, and we have good visibility on full year, but quarter-by-quarter, it's difficult. But needless to say, Q2 was fairly impressive with revenue up over 40% and EBITDA up over 100%. So that was obviously, a very big quarter for BrandLoyalty. We think we probably don't want to keep that as a run rate going forward, although I'd love to, but I think mid-teens top and bottom would be a good numbers set of number for the year. 
Also as Charles mentioned, the BrandLoyalty U.S. pilot has been completed, has been very successful. We need to be able to careful about chatting about what's next, but we have very high hopes in terms of upcoming activity in the U.S. 
Now let's turn to Canada and AIR MILES' revenue was up 6% and I believe it was up 5% in Q1. EBITDA for Q2 was up 4% and EBITDA in Q1 was up 11%. 
So I think the bottom line of all of it is that there's been murmurs out there that the Canadian business is too mature and that it's not really going anywhere and that it's very sluggish. This is a solid mid-single-digit top and bottom with very strong cash flow generation. This is a great business, and I think it's going to be around for a long time, and that's why we keep it firmly as part of the assets within Alliance, so very pleased with that issuance. Again, jumps by quarter. It was up 5% in Q1, it was down 3% in Q2. I think on a full year basis, we're still shooting for somewhere around 4% or something like that. So overall, we did have over performance versus guidance. It came from 3 areas. First, on the top line basis, Epsilon's revenues swung faster than we had anticipated, 7-point swing versus we were looking at more like 4 or 5. 
Second, in Card Services, yields came in better than expected as we saw the burn through of these programs occur faster, and that was good news. 
And then finally, on the bottom line, it didn't help top line, but on the bottom line, as Charles said, we accelerated the opportunity to take the final 20% of BrandLoyalty and that added a few pennies in addition to the other stuff. 
So probably those 3 things drove the over performance, but in general, really, across the board, it was a really good story. 
I think on a full year basis, let's just jump to that. We are raising full year guidance to revenues of $7.15 billion, up 11%. Core EPS of $16.85, up 12% and the new guidance does reflect the flow through of the second quarter be to our guidance. And we'll flow through additional over performance, if any, if it occurs in the back half of the year. 
Essentially, this year has been playing out, neither Charles nor I want to get too far out over our skis here so what we're effectively doing is we'll flow through the over performance when it comes, but let's not go charging down the road too quickly right now. Certainly, things are heading in the right direction, there's an upward bias to the even existing guidance, but when it comes, we'll flow it through. You can think of it almost as a hedge against foreign exchange rates going wonky, again. We don't want to have to recut and go through all that stuff, again. But in general, back half looks good, second quarter, obviously, double double look very good. 
Card Services, we still expect double-digit growth, top and bottom for the year. Yield compression, we'll continue to lessen each quarter, and we went from 2 10 to 80, and it will continue to lessen as the final 2 quarters play out, which gives us, again, from where Melisa and I said a very nice jump up points for next year. 
Principal loss rates, a lot of chatter out there in the marketplace, losses are going up, they're going up faster, they're going up slower. It's pretty straightforward. We're seeing the seasoning we thought at the beginning of the year, we'll do 5% and then the other 50 basis points next year. So we're not seeing any consumer distress and the new vintages that we're signing, we have already completed the $2 billion in signings we needed for the full year this year. So it's only July, but again, a wonderful year. 
Epsilon, revenue growth rate snapped back to mid-single. We expect that to drift up a bit and improve and even Q3 in Q4 at the moment and continues. We expect the revenue flow through to EBITDA starting as soon as Q3 as India is fully ramped up. And again, we'll call it the Q3 flip. 
Digital & technology  businesses are hot. As Charles mentioned, double-digit growth, it's 3 quarters of Epsilon-Conversant so it's by far, the largest chunk of it, and it is doing extremely well. 
The final piece, the quarter of the business that's agency and media and media services, again, better than Q1, still has some work to do. We have a number of initiatives underway. I guess, the overall way to think about Epsilon and Conversant is that we manage a portfolio of products and services that can range from products that are in decline 15%, 20% to those that are going over 60%. The goal here is to manage to a way that average growth rate into the mid- to high single digits. And so I think we're back on track there. 
And on the agency side specifically, we have a number of initiatives underway, specifically sort of a data-driven CRM light if you want to call it for clients who don't want to do the full scale heavy-duty CRM offering, but also potentially looking at maybe a white label type approach to the platform, offering up to the mid-tier and smaller agencies that can afford to bring all that stuff in-house. So again, I think there's a bunch of good stuff going on there that we're still feeling pretty optimistic about it. 
Finally, and then we'll take some questions, LoyaltyOne. We expect mid-single-digit growth in revenue on a constant currency basis. And as I said, this is a -- it's a good business, and it continues to get good traction up there. 
AIR MILES issued also about 4% and then, of course, BrandLoyalty strong double-digit top and bottom line growth as the business continues to expand globally. 
All right, overall, if you were to look at the bigger picture, in the longer-term picture, you would see that if you went from the year before the Great Recession and then including the Great Recession and all the way up to last year, this company has delivered top line growth averaging 15% a year and bottom line growth, of core EPS growth of 18% a year. And again, that includes the Great Recession. So it's not all that surprising that we're already back to double-digit top and bottom. Again, I think it's recorded ahead of schedule, but we are raising guidance and expect to be running at plus 11 and plus 12 for rev and core EPS. It's the ability to grow our core EPS by double digits despite being in a period of normalization in our card business. So what does that all mean? Would it essentially means is we're dumping a whole bunch of P&L expense, not cash expense but P&L expense into our reserves as losses normalize and as we are growing 20-plus percent, it's a big drag on our numbs, and you're talking a couple hundred million dollars and what that effectively does is that knocks 10 points off our of growth rate. And so even in its big higher growth period with big reserve builds, we're still able to deliver double-digit top and bottom, that's pretty good. And so if we can do plus 11 top, plus 12 bottom, essentially in a period where you're done seasoning in loss rate to stable, that would have been plus 11 and plus 22. So that's the order of magnitude here. Our goal is even in a seasoning period, which is what we're in now, we still expect to deliver double top, double bottom. 
Okay. So I think that our business outlook looks good, and I think if we don't have anything else here, we just might go to Q&A. Obviously, you can tell from our tone that what once was a very heavily weighted back in this year is no longer the case, and we're feeling pretty cheerful about it. 
So why don't we open it up to Q&A?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Nice to see the strong second quarter results and increased outlook for the year. Melisa, I appreciate the helpful insight and the Card Services. With credit top of mind, can you just remind us what the FICA score ranges are for your customer base and how these are trending with new customer additions?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a situation, really, David, we don't really look at it that way. The underwriting that we do is a combination of internal proprietary data that we use, plus bureaus that we pull as well. So it's really a combination we use. If you think about the und
componenttext: It's a situation, really, David, we don't really look at it that way. The underwriting that we do is a combination of internal proprietary data that we use, plus bureaus that we pull as well. So it's really a combination we use. If you think about the underwriting table we've been using the same approach since the early '90s so it's a very mature, it's part of our secret sauce. So it's not a case where we purely rely on bureaus, it's more of a case using we're using our internal data, which is, as you know, extensive to really a universe of consumers that meet our profile but also will be different, part of the reason we get the growth rates we do. So I'd say it's what we would said before, we don't target subprime, we're going for a prime consumer, but we don't really rely upon bureaus as 100% of underwriting.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, if I can just add on top of that, we have invested pretty significantly in tools that allow us to look at data sources even beyond that which would be our standard either from other outside sources or that which we have internally. And we belie
componenttext: And David, if I can just add on top of that, we have invested pretty significantly in tools that allow us to look at data sources even beyond that which would be our standard either from other outside sources or that which we have internally. And we believe that combination is a bit of our secret sauce. It allows us to welcome as many card members to the program that will actually pay us back, but also really accretive to our brand partners.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Just shifting gears, ValueAct recently increased its stake to 6.8% of ADS and they spelled out some objectives in the press release. Can you enlighten us about your dialogue with ValueAct and where you think that will go over time?
componenttext: Understood. Just shifting gears, ValueAct recently increased its stake to 6.8% of ADS and they spelled out some objectives in the press release. Can you enlighten us about your dialogue with ValueAct and where you think that will go over time?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I certainly read the press release. I would say that what we can say is that they have known us extremely well for probably a decade, and they been's quite savvy with their bets over the past decade and the initial discussions we have had is very si
componenttext: Sure, I certainly read the press release. I would say that what we can say is that they have known us extremely well for probably a decade, and they been's quite savvy with their bets over the past decade and the initial discussions we have had is very similar to the discussions we'll have with any potential large investor, which is tell us about the business, the plan, the future kind of believe is just what they said that they think it's a good value, and they think that the noise around the whole credit and how it's going to impact us and everything else is overdone, and that's what we've been told in terms of their position. Anything else frankly, I believe they have to file certain papers if they decide to do something else. But frankly, that's all we know at this point.

componenttext: Quick question on some of the initiatives around Epsilon redirecting the digital agency towards mid-agencies and the like. I mean, how long do you think this takes to really assess whether or not it works or not?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's -- what we're seeing on that small piece in the agency side is that the traditional clients we have, the real big agencies have taken a lot of that work in house, right? Because the goal of that part of the business was originally to go
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's -- what we're seeing on that small piece in the agency side is that the traditional clients we have, the real big agencies have taken a lot of that work in house, right? Because the goal of that part of the business was originally to go out and find inventory, an appropriate inventory where we could place the various advertisements and messaging. And so as that has happened in programmatic trading and everything else has come into play, what we're looking at and where we think there's a big opportunity is there's a lot of clients out there who love the huge CRM type offering that requires them to give us the SKU level information, both online, off line. We take that, we turn it to the big machines, we find the right patterns, we go out and place those with the appropriate folks out in the digital space. But there's also, we believe, a huge chunk of folks, clients out there who don't necessarily want or need the whole soup to nuts that we offer with big CRM as we call it. So I'm going to call it CRM light, which is where you use some data. So for example, client me just say, look, I'm having a big sale, it's going to be in the southeast region of the country. I want to go out and I want to find these folks who are most likely to visit. Here's my email list, could you go out, use that data and let everyone know that's appropriate about the sale and what's going on? And that's a much smaller commitment from the client, and we think that's a good way to get them in the door and hopefully, eventually up sell to big CRM. So the long-winded answer is, if we can do that, along with our partners at, let's say, the mid-tier agencies who can afford to build these massive trading platforms, programmatic type platforms, that this could be a nice winner and a nice feeder as well into the CRM. We've already started the retraining of our agency sales folks into CRM. And so we expect this thing to start taking root really towards the back half of the year. So hopefully, we'll see some results before we exit this year.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then I just have a second question of Private Label, and maybe it's for Melisa and all of you. Yes, there's obviously always chatter about large renewals for all the big Private Label issuers, and you guys included. But can you just conce
componenttext: Okay, great. And then I just have a second question of Private Label, and maybe it's for Melisa and all of you. But can you just conceptually talk about your confidence in retaining some of your larger customers as they've grown with you, perhaps anecdotally maybe you could just talk about, if any, of those sales, the sales lift commentary that Melisa had still apply to these big relationships as your relationship has evolved?

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Sanjay, good morning. I'm glad you asked that question because these sales gains that we talked about are really from those legacy programs. And candidly, we have a high degree of confidence that we will retain those partners where we are like-minded, where they view the card program as the ultimate loyalty tools, where we're both making joint investments into the program. Candidly, tender share increases, increasing spend and retention is really how our partners measure us, and it's the report card that we have for ourselves. So we would tell you this that we have a 100% track record of retaining those important brand partners where we are aligned on the bowls of the program. And we intend to approach the future just the same way that we approach the past.

componenttext: Again, a lot of it comes to timing. I'd say some of it is going to be driven by BrandLoyalty. Our BrandLoyalty saw with revenues down 10% in Q1, up 40% in Q2. It will likely drop to maybe negative Q3 and then big pop in Q4. As you know, BrandLoyalty is a high fixed cost structures so as its revenue ramps so you get a nice flow through earnings. It's just items like that, that have that influence. The CRM business with Conversant, it is a very much backup driven on the holiday season. You could get a nice wrap. So there, it's not one single factor. It's just a number of factors that drive the growth you're looking sequentially Q3, Q4.

componenttext: Yes, Darrin. I'll go ahead and answer the question if I can in reverse order. With respect to consumer behavior, candidly, we're  just not seeing the distrust in terms of her payment behavior and her shopping behavior that others have discussed. Now she's shopping differently and she is spending differently. And part of the advantage that we have here, as you know, we've diversified our portfolio a bit, so apparel seems to be the area where we see some weakness. But in terms of her payment behavior and her relationship with us, we have great visibility into where she spent and great visibility into how she's going to continue to behave with us. So again, we feel very comfortable with leading guidance for the year. With respect to what has changed from the end of last year, recall that we didn't make some program changes and the risk mix -- excuse me, the vintage mix of our new partners was also influencing what those yields look like. And simply as Ed said, we are ahead a quarter. The burn in and the normalization just have happen sooner than we expected. And again, was very good visibility into that the future looks like, we feel very, very good about meeting that guidance.

headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me, I want to hit the credit thing because there's -- there seems to be so much chatter out there that it may be helpful to put it in perspective and having been in the business for 1,000 years here going back to the '90s and the various cycles t
componenttext: Yes, let me, I want to hit the credit thing because there's -- there seems to be so much chatter out there that it may be helpful to put it in perspective and having been in the business for 1,000 years here going back to the '90s and the various cycles to where we are today, I think probably the biggest stress test that anyone has ever faced was the great recession. And in the Great Recession, what actually happened was that even though Private Label tends -- it always has run a point-or-so above loss rates in sort of the general-purpose arena. What actually happened in the Great Recession is we performed a lot better in the general-purpose cards, and so what it really hit the fan, the general-purpose cards, those portfolios went from 4%, 5% to 10% or 11% loss rate. I mean, 600 basis points. We went up 300 and the reason behind that is why, I guess, we don't share the concern that others do about Private Label and everything else is the fact that for sure, it's a card that doesn't have utilization of a general-purpose card but that's great in terms of when times get stretched because of the fact that you do not have a big open up byline, and you do not have the ability to go use it to buy food and put gas in the gas and then go bankrupt. So what you're seeing is there may be lots of cards out there, but as you go down the credit spectrum, you bring down your credit lines, and so you may have $100 credit line on someone with a thin file and that the ability to manage or open to buy and your credit lines across 40 million households is what allowed us to really manage to a very modest hit during the Great Recession, and that's why I think we don't expect to see any spike because we are very active in terms of managing credit lines.

componenttext: Yes, it's a great question. I think in North America, if you look at where we started, we started up in Canada, obviously, it made sense as we have all this relationships with a big grocers. Pedal is to the metal in Canada, and that's bringing in $40 million, $50 million a year of incremental revenue since we started probably 18 months ago. So Canada is fully spooled up. And so you're left with the U.S, which is 10x in terms of the market size of Canada, which get us, obviously, pretty excited. We were very deliberate in the pilots that we've been running. All we can say at this point is that the results were quite good and the results we expect that the client is hopefully as excited as we are and hopefully, we'll have some bigger news before the end of the year. That's unfortunately what we can see at this point but once that happens, then we press the accelerator a little bit more.

componenttext: Yes, Ramsey. Here's what we would say. We have been thriving in a very heavily regulated environment for many, many years. We obviously stay very close to pending points of view to any actions that are taken out there. For us on the deferred side, it is not a significant portion of the business, and so we would respond accordingly, if there was any feedback that was given. And for us, next to our partners and our consumers, we take our reputation with the regulators very, very seriously. So we build strong relationships and build our business accordingly.

componenttext: Bob, we would tell you that this growth as you well know, has been very purposeful, very planned like all of the other institutions, we've dramatically strengthening our areas of compliance, compliance management systems. componenttext: Well, it's certainly out crowded competitive field right now, Bob. componenttext: I hope I can sneak in 2 here real quick. First one us, Ed, just going back to the free cash flow and sort of thinking about that nominal number versus how you allocate that internally what's there for the repurchase program, which you've executed on, but obviously, you're growing the bank and the receivables, and you look at some of the regulatory portion as you're putting capital to one of the banks. headline: Alliance Data Systems Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll give it to at a high level and Charles can put any detail that he wants. But at very high level, when I look at capital allocation and capital resources for any given year, I start with sort of our general definition of EBITDA, net of funding co
componenttext: Yes, I'll give it to at a high level and Charles can put any detail that he wants. But at very high level, when I look at capital allocation and capital resources for any given year, I start with sort of our general definition of EBITDA, net of funding cost and of corporate interest expense, net of CapEx. You add back sort of the delta between the provision and where our actual cash losses are, and you come up with about $1.4 billion of that amount if cards is growing, the file $3 billion a year, something like that, we're going to need $450 million to $500 million of capital to support that, you take that out of $1.4 billion, you're down to $900 million and that essentially is what we have to play with without sort of increasing the leverage a lot. But sort of that $900 million is sort of what we play with and that either goes towards buyback or it goes towards M&A. And look, the M&A could be at the bank level with the portfolio. In that case, we would keep a little bit more down the bank or it could be M&A for an Epsilon or LoyaltyOne. In that case, we would upstream it to the parent. So that's essentially the breakdown of our free cash flow.
